All I Do Is Listen is a Melbourne based blog about new Australian music. I_éìve got a lot of time for All I Do Is Listen. I can_éìt rightly express why I like it so much but I just do. It could be because founder Thomas Lukaitis has impeccable taste or it could be because he introduced me to one of my favourite Australian EPs in D.D. Dumbo. Whatever the case, this is a pretty cracking blog. The sheer amount of work that_éìs invested to be posting almost daily across a number of features such as new, videos, interviews and mixtapes is more than I_éìm willing to invest in anything, ever, including both my dayjob and my marriage. I joke, I joke. But seriously, what about that work ethic, AMIRIGHT!? It_éìs a Melbourne based outfit and if you wanna stay hip to the game then I recommend you invest right here where the standard fare is garage rock and electrindie. Maybe don_éìt hit _éïlike_éì on facebook though, he_éìs smoking me on social media and I don_éìt like that one bit, NO SIR.

Welcome to Allston Pudding, your online source for music both in Boston and beyond. Allston Pudding is operated and written by fans and musicians to highlight new music and live music from all over. We are supporters of local music, whether it is in our hometown, or in other local scenes throughout the world. We hope to support and champion artists who may not receive their proper radio play or publicity, but definitely deserve your attention. Take a read and enjoy

DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: American Aftermath is here to promote and support the music we, and hopefully you, love: Metal. All types of metal. Black, Death, Thrash, Power, Grindcore, Hardcore, Metalcore, Sludge and on occasion, Grunge. We also dabble in punk and obscure hip-hop.

We are a teeny tiny blog and cherish all who visit our pages-The future is bright and while we cover all sorts of artists, our main focus is to write about those bands that deserve attention but may not be getting covered by Pitchfork, Stereogum or Spin magazine. There is so much great music out there and artists busting their ass, playing gigs at all sorts of places, hoping just one person will listen.

AOR Disco was started in 2009 by Matthew Hamilton with a mission to rediscover the lost golden age of Adult Orientated Rock. From the beardy acoustic era of late 1960s Laurel Canyon to the white-suited Yacht Rock yuppies of the early 1980s, AOR Disco seeks out the best in vintage Californian drive-time hits, soft-rock disco, psychedelic funk, and the kind of obscure album tracks you might find at the back of your dad's record collection

Apoch's Metal Review is a website dedicated to bring light to the best releases from the underground to the major players, and educate people why they are good, or what it is that makes them bad. Examined under the critical and unbiased eye of an open minded former Metal Director for WSFX FM, the mission is simple: To weed out the bullshit in Metal today.

mp3 blog

Based in Los Angeles, Aquarium Drunkard is an eclectic audio blog featuring daily music reviews, interviews, features, mp3 samples and sessions. Originating in 2005, digging globally, the Drunkard bridges contemporary sounds with vintage garage, psych, folk, country, soul, funk, r&b and everything that falls in between.Helmed by Justin Gage, the blog has since spun off Autumn Tone Records, the Aquarium Drunkard Presents series, the Lagniappe Sessions and the weekly, two hour, Aquarium Drunkard Show airing Fridays on SIRIUS/XMU (channel 35), Noon-2pm EST. Gage is a working music supervisor for film and music consultant. He authored the 2009 guide/travelogue Memphis And The Delta Blues Trail.

DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: This blog. A one-stop shop for the best new music releases across genres out of Detroit. A one-stop shop for finding local music events, from Jazz at Cliff Bells to a more debaucherous after-hours ghettotech show at the Rager Haus. Welcome to At Cost Magazine. Coming from sister blog Swede + Sour, a hypemachine-listed bedroom blog which filled the niche for English-written content on Scandinavian pop music, At Cost seeks a more expansive approach and its aim is to cover more interviews, in-depth articles and longer thought-pieces. Essentially what you see here is what you get, and welcome to At Cost where everything advertised is of face value. Absolutely no click-bait, no shock-tactics, no fluff pieces or paid-pieces (although I wish this was true), just content as I see fit.

Musical Background: Howdy fellow musicheads, I_éìm Adam aka Akwitz and a self-proclaimed music aficionado.  I_éìm a lover and collector of music as well as a musician myself.  I_éìm a classically trained tenor singer, have done my fair share of lyric writing in the past and dabble a bit at guitar.  I grew up in Baltimore, which has it_éìs own brand of local music scene and lived in NYC for 6 years, two of which I spent working in the music industry at Warner Music Group which only diversified my musical tastes more.  I have since moved back to and reside in Baltimore and am an avid concert-goer and record store peruser.  I listen to music 24/7 and I am constantly discovering new and up-and-coming music that all I want to do is share with the world; and that is what this blog is all about.Musical tastes: I like to claim I have a very eclectic musical palette, but tend to stick mostly to music of a rock-based lineage, although I do appreciate other forms and genres.

Backseat Mafia started in November 2012, as a result of an accident. Literally. The founder of the website, Jim, fell and broke several bones in his arm and wrist, only a couple of weeks after having an operation on his knee. Left with several months off work, and unable to do much at all, he started Backseat Mafia as a way of passing the time,The backseat mafia bit comes from one of the bands Jim is in (he_éìs something of a musician), and the previous band manager accused some of them of being like _éïbackseat mafia_éì on the bus and trying to get rid of him. They were, and they did sit at the back, but he always liked the description. Hence_éÙ_éÙ Backseat Mafia

Baeblemusic is a New York-based music site dedicated to providing high quality, originally produced video content that extends far beyond its web-based home and its city borders. With well-trained eyes focused on emerging music scenes, Baeble crafts unique, narrative portraits of prominent and up-and-coming artists and bands. Through its full length concert videos and intimate sessions, Baeble is revolutionizing the way music is consumed by providing free front-row tickets to be enjoyed from the comfort of your own home.With its editorial pages, Baeble is devoted to providing daily coverage on all things music and pop culture. From artist profiles and exclusive features to cynical and observational humor pieces, Baeble's writing staff dissects the news and forecasts the often unpredictable evolution of pop music.

I_éìll be the first person to admit that Beantown Boogiedown (BBD) is nothing special. Music is meant to be played, heard and shared. Bear Toons is an Edinburgh/DC-based source for you to discover music. For quality music from all genres, sources and cultures this is the spot. Its like trying a new type of candy every day of your life: sometimes its too sweet, too sour, too rich but once in while you find one that_éìs crunchy, chewy and just right - its bliss. I hope to give you that feeling every time you come to Bear Toons. Maybe not today, maybe not tomorrow, but someday i_éìll give you a taste of the best damn candybar_éÙerm..song you_éìve never heard before and you_éìll know what I_éìm talking about.

Beautiful Buzzz is a new music blog and event production company based out of San Francisco, CA.  Our goal is to expose up-and-coming artists who we believe are on the cutting edge of indie pop, electronic and dance music.  We believe the world needs to know about the little guys _éç and we love to support independent musicians from around the globe!The name comes from a Rolling Stones song called _é£Loving Cup_éó which happens to be Editor/Founder Erin Maher_éìs favorite song from the British rockers.  It_éìs not a reference to anything else but that _éç but we like to think we have our finger on the pulse of what is buzzing within the indie music scene.  The site caters to those interested in music news and goings on within the Los Angeles, San Francisco, United Kingdom, and Australian music scene, although does not exclude any other regions.The site includes: a new music section, gig guide, links to videos and other interesting music related items around the web, and a mix tape section complied monthly and showcasing some of the best music available at the time of its creation.

As a Music Filter, BitCandy's team (which are indeed humans and not computers) listens to and filters thousands of blog posts, hundreds of new album releases, dozens of indie music publications, along with the word on the street each month to bring you a handpicked, trusted stream of the best content and songs, unknown artists and what_éìs buzzing on the web.BitCandy additionally offers irreverent Music Reviews, a Featured Music section, a Posers section (for the "most hyped music fails") and a cutting edge, weekly posting of the Best Indie Songs, Best Electro Bangers and Best Pop, HipHop Remixes & Mashups. It's BitCandy_éìs belief that we don_éìt need another "5 Million Songs in Our Pocket." No, what we need today is a trusted Music Filter to help discover and serve up just the 100 most amazing new songs on a continual fresh basis, either signed or unsigned_éÙ and to discover and explore great music that will enrich our lives (and get us through Mondays)

Black Grooves is a music review site hosted by the Archives of African American Music & Culture (AAAMC) at Indiana University. Our goal is to promote black music by providing our readers with monthly updates on interesting new releases and quality reissues in all genres_åéincluding gospel, blues, jazz, funk, soul, R&B, world music, and hip-hop_éåas well as classical music composed or performed by black artists. We feature reviews of some of the best new discs and DVDs, with an occasional book or news item thrown in for good measure. An extra effort is made to track down releases by indie, underground, foreign, and other small labels that don_éìt get covered in the mainstream media. Our primary focus is on African American music, but we_éìll be happy to cover anything else that_éìs sent our way, from Afropop to reggae.

DJ with a blog...DJ Rhude has had a long history in the music game as a DJ and writer. Starting out as a long time contributer for XXL Magazine (1999-2008), he has also penned for The Source and King Magazines. During this time, he enhanced his reputation as a DJ known for his mixtapes as well as being able to hold his own in the club. With his name starting to become more popular it led to several television spots one of which was appearances on BET_éìs Rap City as the guest DJ. The turntabalist was also the man behind the idea that sparked the widely successful No Pigeon_éìs record with the Sporty Thieves. It was always Rhude_éìs keen ear for talent that separated him from his peers and kept him ahead of the game. A ton of experiences were born from his musical journey and here at BlockMuzikRadio.com some of those will be shared as well as creating new ones. Rhude will continue to drop mixtape bangers right here on BMR, all the while continuing to document this great culture we call Hip Hop.

It_éìs not just for me to find new artists and music from ANYWHERE in the WORLD, but also for you to discover some great music or if you an artist or band this blog is a chance for you to be posted and shown to the world; if I manage to get one person to like an artist because they saw them on this blog then my mission has been achieved

The purpose of blogtotheoldskool.com is to provide information and audio for lesser known hardcore/jungle releases put out from 1991-1995, as well as info about the artists and labels responsible for them. Mp3s of tracks and live sets are posted, 99.99% of the time ripped direct from the original vinyl. The tracks posted are from long-deleted and hard to find singles, where the only people making money on them now are collectors re-selling them second-hand. No labels which have tracks for sale on sites like BeatPort or Itunes will have tunes posted (if there are links, they will be to those sites rather than to direct mp3s). If you see any track mentioned on this site for sale at a legit mp3 store like beatport, please email and they will be removed. Also, if any artists or labels want their tracks taken down for whatever reason, email and they will be taken down immediately _éç This is not meant as a mp3 dump, but a site to raise awareness about some obscure but great music.

To avoid any confusion, the roots of BraveWords (the website) began in early 1994 with the launch of the _é£Metal_éó Tim Bits _é£baby magazine_éó (as Gene Simmons puts it). In May of 1994, Brave Words & Bloody Knuckles reared its ugly head and soon after it would simply change to BW&BK until its untimely demise in early 2009, a record-setting run for rock music publications in Canada. BraveWords.com launched in 2000 and that is when the overlap and cross-promotion between the magazine and website began. As a result, officially, BraveWords has been waving the flag of hard rock and heavy metal for two decades.

DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: In the first six months, Brutal Resonance has evolved from a Swedish only netzine, to an established International zine of the highest standard. With professional and experienced staff from all over the world, we offer you knowledge on the widest of genres. To answer a commonly asked question, we are truly independent with no special agreements. This means that we will feature any label or artist that falls within our spectrum. Regardless of personal bias, all releases that are featured will be given the scrutiny we believe they deserve. This means that we are not afraid to give something a low score if we dislike it. At risk of controversy, we do firmly believe that we should give an honest opinion. If our staff do not like an album, then we simply will not tell the audience to buy it. However, we do also promise a fair and accurate review.This means that (apart from in rare cases), even the lowest scoring albums will be balanced out, so that the pros and cons are both documented.

Buzz Bands LA was founded in September 2008 as a vehicle for the continuing adventures in music of Kevin Bronson, who the previous six years had authored the Buzz Bands column and blog for the Los Angeles Times.Bronson has a history of tipping readers to myriad unsigned artists such as Silversun Pickups, Cold War Kids, the 88, the Little Ones and the Airborne Toxic Event, and the new Buzz Bands LA continues that tradition, scouting L.A. and environs for the most promising emerging artists, providing crisp interviews and perspective, offering capsulized album and show reviews and touting the best new videos and upcoming shows. His collection of press badges includes the Coachella, Detour, Lollapalooza and SXSW festivals, as well as the Warped Tour. In 2010, Buzz Bands LA was chosen to curate the KCRW-sponsored Also I Like to Rock series at the Hammer Museum.

Buzz is an independent weekly entertainment magazine. Casablanca Sunset began in the fall of 2013. Designed to channel quality music to people around the world, we are a fully focused group of music enthusiasts helping others discover, inspire & inform. The blog started for fun and is based around the love of music. In February of 2014 we were added the Hype Machine music algorithm and currently have five contributing authors. We tend to post independent rock, hip-hop and electronic dance music that you will not find on most radio and broadcast media formats. We strive to publish quality over quantity. In order to have a voice in the music community you need to have an original approach and a commitment to publishing quality content.  We understand this and we follow these ideals with the hopes of continuing to develop a sustainable and reliable music discovery source.We support independent artists and are consistently blown away at the quality of independent music we receive in our inbox every single day. We do our best to listen to everything submitted, but sometimes music falls through the cracks. If you think your music fits our general demographic then feel free to send us your stuff. Submit your music to music@casablancasunset.com. It is preferred that you submit a youtube link of your audio, as well as a Soundcloud link should we decide to post the track. We also prefer that you send a press photo for each submission with a width of at least 750 pixels. We do our best to listen to everything, but unfortunately can not post it all. Do not get discouraged if you do not make the site.
This is the Cat From Japan blog, a place for us to ramble aimlessly about whatever new music we found on the internet that night.

Digital music submissions are strongly preferred, but you may also send them via snail mail. If that_éìs the case, email me and I will provide you with my mailing address.

The Chicago Reader is Chicago's largest free weekly newspaper, nationally recognized as a leader in the alternative press. Since 1971, the Reader has served as Chicago's political conscience, cultural guide, and music authority. With a highly targeted-circulation of 90,000 and a consistent return rate of less than 2%, the Chicago Reader is the city's most essential alternative media resource. Known for its in-depth coverage of Chicago politics and culture, the Reader explores and exposes news, events and issues that affect city living. The paper has won numerous journalistic awards and honors, both local and national, and is well-known as a showcase for Chicago's most talented writers, critics, photographers, and illustrators. With a readership of 450,000 and some of the industry's lowest advertising rates, the Chicago Reader is one of the largest and most successful alternative weeklies in the country.

Cokemachineglow is made up of globally scattered writers united by an inexhaustible desire to write about music two thousand words at a time. We don_éìt have an office space, we don_éìt have golf shirts with a little CMG logo on the front, and some of us don_éìt even know what any of the rest of us look like, but it_éìs no stretch to call what CMG has going a Community, one we're proud of and want more interaction among. Hence: Facebook. We_éìve been at this labor of love for a few years now, and the CMG timeline is littered with events metastasizing from a genuine love of rigorous, funny, sometimes heated debate....

"It_éìs your pal at the bar, that friendly face by the stage, the first bookmark you click on each day. Consequence of Sound is the missing link between mainstream pop culture and the underground.Since its inception in 2007, the Chicago-based online publication has accrued a monthly readership of six million-plus for its reliability, precision, and character with regards to music and film. It_éìs a voice that wants to pat one_éìs shoulders, not stand on them.The Internet is a digital playground. Consequence of Sound is the shiny set of swings that everyone races toward. We work off an enjoyable yet proven philosophy: share the fun. As such, our readers are loyal, persistent, and growing. Now, isn_éìt that what you_éìre looking for?Consequence of Sound was crowned About.com_éìs Best Music Blog of 2010, Technorati_éìs Most Influential Music Blog, and Style of Sound_éìs No. 2 Most Influential Music Blog.Consequence of Sound is featured on Metacritic and Time Entertainment."

Led by founder Bill Tikos, The Cool Hunter celebrates creativity in all of its modern manifestations. Since its inception in 2004 The Cool Hunter has become the world's most-read culture and design site, a leading authority on all things creative and a truly global hub for what's cool, thoughtful, innovative and original. We value global relevance, not trends, channeling our discoveries to our worldwide audience. The Cool Hunter is a natural fit for its readers - creative influencers who stay in the know and ahead of the curve. Global in outlook, culturally discerning, The Cool Hunter readers are connected, creatively aware, confident, stylish and sociable. They value architecture, design, style, music, fashion and entertainment. They work, play and travel internationally and bring with them distinguished tastes and a demanding appetite for quality information. The Cool Hunter is not a trend-spotter, trend-watcher or trend predictor. We select and celebrate what is beautiful and enduring from all that is sought-after in architecture, design, gadgets, lifestyle, urban living, fashion, travel and pop culture. We remain relevant by staying ahead of and outside of trends and fads _éå the fickle shifts in taste and style. The Cool Hunter digs deeper, finding tomorrow's icons and classic phenomena. We are a prized reference point of choice for a global creative community.

I welcome all submissions for review (within reason, if you peddle some lameass R&B or Bieber-style pop, then please feel free to jog on, but anything psychedelic or fuzzy is my thang!. MP3s are preferable for review purposes; streaming is OK but rather at the whim of patchy broadband. I listen, and listen hard, to all submissions, but if it doesn't rock my boat I won't review - please don't take offence, after all this is just my opinion and not a reflection of your skill and creativity as musicians. I'd rather not say anything than say something negative...there's enough negativity in this world.

DEAF SPARROW is an underground and independent music website with a passion for underground music that has been in operation since 2007.  The current site you_éìre viewing was built in 2013 with artwork by George Tourlas.  We have a rotating set of writers, depending on their real life requirements, and one steady editor.Our focus is on a wide variety of music with a big emphasis on the eclectic and extreme.  We review anything that fits this general concept from ambient to shoegaze.  Basically everything in the underground you can think of, so if you have a question, just ask us, or make sure to check our submission policies on the contact page for more details.  Our primary mission is to spread the word, inform and provide a fair but honest assessment of the music we receive, with a special focus on bands and labels with low exposure.  In addition, you can find interviews with bands, records labels, and the like, as well as special features updated throughout the year including _éïBest Of_éì lists, unsigned band round-ups, anime features, and much more.  If you_éìre interested in doing one of our special releases, also check out the contact page for more information.

Inspired by the birth of my son, I created this site with the hopes of exposing myself to new music. There is nothing like watching a child experience the sights and sounds of this world for the first time and like many new parents, I_éìve enjoyed introducing him to albums that have impacted my life.Deana Discovers Music has allowed me to get back to my love of writing about music without any strict guidelines and rules. My goal is to review songs that I have never heard before across all genres and interview creative folks about how music influenced their lives.If you have any feedback or would like to be interviewed for my 5 Questions section, please email me.Deana Morton is a writer and music nerd who left the bright lights of New York City to raise her son in Colorado. She_éìs a runner, amateur gardener, Stevie Nicks enthusiast and working on her first YA novel about a teenage girl who starts a rock n_éì roll band.

Death Metal Underground (DMU) is the oldest and longest-running metal site on the internet with content dating back to 1988. Its mission includes ongoing inspection of heavy metal music, its history, culture, imagery and philosophy.Our analysis originates in two ideas: that heavy metal is a form of art and culture, and that the origins of heavy metal can be found in the late Romantic movement in art and literature whose imagery and ideals it carries to this day.Most people want disposable entertainment that puts no burden of understanding on them. They want something they can project into and then leave without feeling a sense of loss. They want television in audio form. Heavy metal interrupts this process and reconnects distracted people with the life hiding beneath our own mental obstacles.

Decibel is an extremely extreme music and entertainment magazine based out of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Founded in 2004 by a well-intentioned, somewhat studious (let_éìs not forget record-collecting) dude, Decibel_éìs credo was to examine and expose the best extreme music had to offer. We were the new kid on the block, but we knew our noise was louder and nastier than anything out there. To quote ourselves, Decibel was _é£the new noise._éó Since our debut issue (the Dillinger Escape Plan, October 2004), Decibel went from the quiet longhair with the Entombed "Left Hand Path" T-shirt to the Grand Pontificator of all things metal. Now, when we speak, people listen. Maybe they heckle. But, nearly nine years later, Decibel is America_éìs only monthly metal magazine.

Decoder Magazine is an all-volunteer music site devoted to reconciling the apparent forward motion of time with the proliferation of humanity and human expression. That is to say, we enjoy interesting music and value insight into individuals and situations that produce it. We attempt to inquire broadly into the origins of perspective; for example, what may or may not be weird, when, why, and to whom. Sometimes mutation is subtle and in biological terms, even less frequently viable, so our ambition is to disproportionately acknowledge non-institutional proliferation: DIY musicians, experimental composers, bedroom producers, etc, and any other instance of an outcome and a methodology that locates agency in individuals.

Echoes And Dust came to life on a wet Wednesday evening back in 2008 when a group of like minded Indie geeks sat in Islington_éìs Mucky Pup (best jukebox in London!) harping on that there weren_éìt enough websites covering the particular dark corner of Indiedom that we liked to frequent.At that point the thought occurred to us that rather than moaning about it why didn_éìt we get off our collective backsides and do something about it? And thus, Echoes And Dust was born.Since then we have reviewed some several hundred albums, gigs and associated bits and bobs and hopefully become a go-to place for a hardy handful of music enthusiast.

Welcome to the new Epitonic.com. First launched on March 8, 1999, the site was one of the first ever music discovery and editorial sites. Epitonic posted free and legal MP3s available for streaming and download, working directly with thousands of artists and labels. All of the music was selected, written about, and posted by a staff of young DJs, touring artists, record collectors, and music lovers based in San Francisco and Chicago. Due to financial difficulties the site went dormant in 2004. A couple of companies tried to revive it but it remained inactive until one of the original founders Justin Sinkovich reacquired rights to the site in 2010. Epitonic then brought together dozens to help revive the site including many of the original staff and dozens of new contributors. After almost a year of planning and building, Epitonic is officially back, once again helping fans to discover the best in cutting edge music. Epitonic today recaptures the spirit of the original site by curating and filtering underground music, but now utilizes new technology and features that were unfathomable when the site was originally built. The relaunch was timed to March 8th, 2011, the day the site originally launched twelve years ago. Many additional features continue to be deployed as time and budgets allow

About the direction brings about a change little in the blog Konzere, parties and events are still predominantly posted in off-spaces and from the underground. The amount of contributions and the regularity of the update, however, was scaled back.2010-todaythe blog more and more changed over the years away from pure event announcements towards a music blog, which featured both acts from the region as well as exciting, aufstebendende international artists. In October 2012, the blog was after we were somewhat less active the months before, relaunched with a completely new layout.

A musicblog about girls singing in French? Pourquoi?!Did you listen to any of the mp3s? Did you hear the girls sing with their high, breathy voices, songs about love, lust, broken hearts, nasty men, the weather, fairytales? And you weren_éìt enchanted, you did not feel butterflies in your belly, you did not feel the urge to write poetry by candlelight, or stare out of the window and sigh, just sigh from time to time? Strange. I do.Why French?It_éìs the language of love, what can I say? Carla Bruni told me (face to face, yes) that it_éìs impossible to write simple songs in French. Lyrics have to be smart, otherwise they get plain stupid. You cannot write a song like, say, Love Me Do in French, and still sound good. Lio_éìs Bananasplit being the only exception.

We are just a couple of guys who really like music. So one night, we were sitting around and figured we would do something with that. Hey, we are smart, good looking, popular with the ladies (can we maybe get 1 out of 3?); so we figured maybe people would stop by. We would give them a venue where they could steal our shit, throw it on facebook, and pretend to be half as cool as we think we are. Basically, we love cool stuff. Whether it's music, clothes, gadgets, stories, or whatever. We want it all.

The new generation of beat smiths understands Hip Hop, Techno and the diverse new styles between electronic and organic grooves evolving from them, not as a mere pose, but as an aesthetic principle, exploring the boundaries of these musical styles.Therefore, the crucial artistic questions are _éç How can you make known subjects in other contexts and how abstract can it be? How do the individual environments, experiences and personal circumnstances influence the artists and how is this reflected in their music?We can now gather some of these arising artists on this concept, allowing you to become familiar with these extraordinary musicians.

From humble origins, throwing a one-off party for charity in their home city of Leeds, Flux has grown in the three years since its inception to become one of the UK_éìs leading providers of underground house, techno and disco. In the past year, Flux has also expanded beyond its Leeds base to throw parties in the capital and across the rest of Europe. With a rapidly expanding multi-faceted website and blog, and with further exciting projects in the pipeline, Flux continues to go from strength to strength, both in events and the wider music scene. Flux's continued success was formally recognised by DJ Mag in 2013 when they were nominated for the UK's Best Club Night

My name is Matthew Perpetua, and I_éìve been writing Fluxblog on nearly every weekday since February of 2002. I live in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and I grew up in a small town called Cold Spring, which is located about 80 minutes north of Manhattan. I am a graduate of Parsons School of Design, but I have not done much in the way of visual art for a while. (It_éìs expensive.)I am an associate editor for RollingStone.com and contribute to Pitchfork. I have also written for Slate, New York Magazine_éìs Vulture, NPR, Associated Press, Spin Magazine, eMusic and MTV. I was the music producer of Public Radio International_éìs Fair Game with Faith Salie up until the show_éìs unfortunate cancellation in June of 2008.

Absolutmetal has been bringing real metal to the underground faithful since 1997 when it began as a print mag. We cover METAL here, bands who are actually out there because they care about the music, bands keeping real metal alive. This is a 'zine for fans, by fans.

This is the third incarnation of the Funky16Corners Blog. It originated in 2004 on Blogger, and moved to WordPress (the free blogging service) two years later because Blogger was an unreliable piece of shit.WordPress was fantastic, easy to use and reliable. I stayed there another three years, until they went on a tear shutting down MP3 blogs (without warning) for what I can only assume were DMCA/copyright notices. Funky16Corners wasn_éìt shut down (or threatened) but I wasn_éìt about to have five years of work go into the toilet, so I decided to figure out how to set up the blog on my own server using the WordPress platform.I have been writing about music in various forms (zines, newspapers, e-zines, blogs) since the mid-80_é_s. The Funky16Corners blog started in November of 2004 to focus on funk and soul vinyl. Since mid-2006, in addition to individual MP3 tracks, I have been posting mixes under the title Funky16Corners radio. Most MP3s and mixes will be available for a few weeks.

Should you have something you feel we should hear, please do send it along. Do note that Future Classics refrains from posting previews. We are extra picky about mix_éìs, and preference is given to music submitted with free download links.

GET SOME was established in Autumn 2009 to showcase the best of UK underground talent. It is a music and arts blog, a party, and most recently a record label. We want to provide a platform for the best creatives of all disciplines to get their work to a wider audience.

Getting Deeper is a Mumbai, India based electronic music blog. Lush vibes, melodic intricacies and sublime mindstates are places we constantly strive to reach through the music we publish. We also like to encourage escapism, philosophical meanderings and sometimes indulging in the dark side of things. In simple words, we like to get deep.
Hand-picked musical delights coupled with a short wittering
Ghettoblaster is a quarterly music and cultural magazine (but primarily music, as we feel most culture is highly overrated).

This blog is an effort to share the love of rare, oddball and under-appreciated music of many kinds. I do my best to limit download links to out-of-print or vinyl & cassette only releases. I encourage each and every one of you to purchase good new releases from your favorite independent retailer. Dig it.
Founded in 2012, Ghost Cult Magazine is dedicated to exploring the boundaries of heavy music
Giant Scary Things is a place to discover new music. It's our mission to search the web for the next big bands and bring them into the spotlight. Check in for new posts every few days!

Established in New York in 1990, we started out of a genuine passion for music. Launched as The Groove Academy we promoted shows of our music heroes - artist such as Bootsy Collins, Gil Scott Heron, George Clinton and Maceo Parker _éç we literally looked up in the phone book. Not long after Giant Step was born as a weekly club that was the breeding ground helping to introduce and break artists such as Jamiroquai, Massive Attack,  Groove Collective, Gangstarr and Digable Planets.As Giant Step evolved over the years we have continued our commitment to introducing great music through our events, website and social networks.Today, the Giant Step community is made up of music lovers, artists, tastemakers and DJs that have grown with the company over the last 20 years. It is a diverse global collective of individuals, united by a common belief in and appreciation for music, innovation, originality and creativity

So much more than voice, instruments, notes, and sound _éç music is a powerful medium that can point us to much bigger things.Within those tiny components giants stomp, and run, and laugh, and shout. Giants such as passion, belief, emotion, and beauty.This is a blog where I explore artists and songs that show me the Giants In The Sound.
All the latest music news, photos, reviews, interviews and more...

The multi award winning GigsandFestivals.co.uk is an online live music publication that includes a vast variety of music news, live reviews, interviews, photo galleries, competitions and festival information. _éïGigs and Festivals_éì covers all genres of music, which caters to the eclectic and diverse music tastes of its readers, from upcoming artists, to the big names in music today. _éïGigs and Festivals_éì aims to keep every music lover up-to-date with the happenings of the current live music scene all year round.

GIGsoup is a cutting edge music magazine. It offers daily music news, music reviews, gig tickets and the best place to leave your views and comments about todays and yesterdays music scene
A UK based music blog focused on DIY, Garage Rock, Indie, Folk and a few other things too

Stockholm-based web radio station airing new alternative sounds on a 24-hour basis, focusing on independently released (or unsigned) artists mainly from Scandinavia, UK, Australia/New Zealand and North America.The radio was founded as a non-profit initiative by Tommy Ericsson in Stockholm, Sweden in June, 2008. Between 2010 and 2012 more than two hundred concerts at venues and festivals around Scandinavia were live streamed to our website. Most of them are now available to stream on-demand in our archive.

New reviews are posted every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday.

We love music. We blog about music. We go to live shows. We listen to new music. We enjoy discovering great new music and sharing it. Our preference lies in alternative/indie and electronic music yet we_éìre certainly open to all kind of genres. On glamglare you find: concert reviews, album reviews, band discoveries, song pick of the day, the video of the week, 3 Is A Band (#3IsABand) write-ups, music quote 'posters', digital mixed tapes, and lots and lots of photos that we took. Living in Brooklyn, this all has a New York spin to it but music is, of course, universal!

The magazine is daily updated and contains all the latest new and announcements from the world of music in the UK. Big to small bands, singer songwriters to death metal, whatever is off interest to our editorial staff.

Gowhere Hip Hop (GWHH) is the #1 tastemaker platform for the hip hop culture. We bring visitors the latest in mainstream and underground hip hop and R&B in addition to a spotlight on the local Chicago hip hop scene. The website is updated daily with the latest news, free downloads, music videos, and more. Users now have the ability to upload their own content, which removes the 'gatekeeper' aspect and opens up the conversation for anyone to get their voice and talents heard _éå letting Hip Hop gowhere it wants to go organically _éå driven by the people, for the people!

GENRE: Indie / Alt / All / Rock / Pop / Hip Hop / Jazz / EDM
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Our project is to start a small webzine / music blog. Certainly, the idea is more than trivial, view and review, but at least it would OUR OUR blog sauce. We would like to launch a site that brasserait all musical styles, or almost: Classical Music, Jazz, to Rock, Rap, the House, Techno, news and junk.
Music blog based in Amsterdam

Since then GIITTV has grown and expanded massively in the last five years, we now cover a wide range of music including unsigned, independent and major releases. God Is in the TV Zine is currently staffed by a range of professional and amateur music journalists. We_éìve always allowed our writers a creative and editorial freedom to express themselves on site, reviewing and dissecting the latest releases, and championing acts that they love.GIITTV has also been a platform for performances and releases. We have promoted gigs in London and Cardiff under the GIITTV zine banner. In 2005 GIITTV put on an event in London_éìs Pleasure compilation CD, it included bands like Luxembourg, The Art Goblins and 1984 (who went on to become Reverend and the Makers). Since then we have promoted nights featuring exciting acts like Frightened Rabbit, Screaming Tea Party, Orphans & Vandals, Her name is Calla, Popular Workshop, and many more.In 2006, GIITTV released a compilation of underground acts including Rose Kemp, Penny Broadhurst, and The International Karate Plus. On June 25, 2007, GIITTV launched their singles club, offering some exclusive free downloads.The first of which came from London Shoegazers Time.Space.Repeat whose track _éïEnd of the World_éì received acclaim from everyone from Tom Robinson to Artrocker magazine. We_éìve since released free singles from anti folk hero Superman Revenge Squad, post rockers The Sailplanes and widescreen indie band My First Radio.Showing that GIITTV also offers invaluable experience in the music business for its writers as well as musicians and artists. In November 2009, GIITTV_éìs singles sub editor Simon Catling won the Record Of The Day_éìs Student Music Journalist Of The Year Award. Other writers for the site have gone on to work for the NME, Clash Magazine, The Guardian and Drowned In Sound amongst others.Expanding upon our commitment to showcase new artists, GIITTV recently launched introducing the band a feature that not only collects new acts that are catching our ears in a link tape, but also gives one selected act the floor of GIITTV for a month. In that month they will receive an interview, features, and share their play list with our readers, we feel that in a music world of hype and fast turnover the ability to really focus on an act that is worthy of attention in detail and over a month gives you greater insight into their music.

Going Solo is the first Italy-based music blog that actually cares about new music.It is curated by a bunch of guys who are tired about the way the people involved into Italian musical press are only concerned about making _é£the most of the clicks_éó out of the latest (terribile) Pearl Jam album review and Miley Cyrus-related tabloid news, instead of actually _éïdo something_éì for the music itself.We also can_éìt accept the way most of the critics who write about music in Italy think about themselves as superior, more influent authorities than bloggers, while we all know that there are many bloggers around (think of the guys behind GvB, NFOP, AdHoc, etc.) that have an actual impact on the _éïmusic scene_éì they cover. This is something that no one in Italy can currently say about himself
GoldFlakePaint is a Bristol-based independent music webzine. We focus on news, reviews, interviews and live sessions regarding any band or artist we find enjoyable.
GoldFlakePaint is a Bristol-based independent music webzine. We focus on news, reviews, interviews and live sessions regarding any band or artist we find enjoyable.
Tel Aviv...Gold Soundz Blog is our outlet for posting mp3s and videos of songs we like from bands all over the world and ranting about music or pop culture

Our musical tastes span from our prepubescent love of cheesy TRL pop, Backstreet Boys and N*SYNC, to Coachella soundtrack hipsters, We Are Scientists, to the new class of pop punk, The Wonder Years and Fireworks.We_éìre not the girls who_éìll turn heads with our exteriors, and that_éìs fine_éÙ Yeah, (some) artsits are attractive, but I never got into writing to bang anyone. I mean some firefighters are smoldering, you don_éìt see me training with a hose_éÙ Simply put, Golden Mixtape wasn_éìt started to be _é£cool_éó because after two decades, if we haven_éìt achieved it, we never will. Golden Mixtape was created so a group of outspoken girls who love creativity in music, TV, and movies could put their mark somewhere other than in each others Twitter feeds.

"When we want to hear exceptional new music_éçnot just anything, but stuff selected by people with respectable eardrums_éçwe go to Gorilla vs. Bear_éÙGvsB_éìs picks are knowledgeable yet friendly; they want you to hear it because they love it. And if another blogger found it first, they_éìre only too happy to give credit where it_éìs due._éçthe morning newsGorilla vs. Bear is a Texas-based music blog. Once called _é£the New Yorker of hipster blogs,_éó we blog about relevant artists of the day, with no particular genre-specific focus. Newsweek thinks we_éìre _é£influential._éóIn 2008, Gorilla vs. Bear was recognized by Rolling Stone as one of the web_éìs _é£Best Music Blogs_éó in the publication_éìs annual Best of Rock issue. GvsB was also voted _é£Blog of the Year_éó in URB Magazine_éìs annual readers poll, beating out such luminaries as Kanye West and the Huffington Post. In 2009, GvsB was named one of the _é£25 Best Music Websites_éó by The Independent UK, alongside famous weblogs eMusic, the Hype Machine, Pitchfork, and Kanye West.In addition, Gorilla vs. Bear hosts an award-winning weekly 2 hour show on Sirius/XM Satellite Radio, and frequently presents live shows in Dallas, Austin, and beyond. We enjoy documenting our favorite artists via various antiquated photographic media, prompting the Village Voice to proclaim, _é£Gorilla vs Bear may have the Polaroid mugshot game on Kryptonite lock._éó (gorilla vs. bear polaroids in the New York Times)"

We enjoy documenting our favorite artists via various antiquated photographic media, prompting the Village Voice to proclaim, _é£Gorilla vs Bear may have the Polaroid mugshot game on Kryptonite lock._éó (gorilla vs. bear polaroids in the New York Times)"

GospelPundit.com is a gospel music website that offers new music, videos, album reviews, news, interviews, articles, giveaways and more. When it launched in November of 2008, GospelPundit.com made its mark as one of the first gospel music blogs, offering frequent updates on all things _é£gospel._éó The site became one of the most visited in gospel music, serving as the premiere web destination for new, accurate and uplifting information in the gospel music community.

Gothamist is the first site in the Gothamist LLC network of blogs and is the most popular local blog in New York. Founded in early 2003, Gothamist has been described by The New York Times as a "marvelous, not-to-be-missed Web site" that "reflects everything worth knowing about this city." Forbes described Gothamist as a "sophisticated, deliciously urbane city blog". In 2007, Gothamist won a Rave Award from Wired Magazine and in 2008, Business Week named Gothamist as a top blog in their annual Best of the Web. Gothamist, as well as a number of other sites in the network, also ranked amongst the most informative blogs in an academic study by Carnegie Mellon.Traffic is currently at 12.7 million pages per month and growing.

GroundFloorGo is a music blog dedicated to covering independent artists on the rise. The main focus is to expose newer artists and bands not receiving the coverage they deserve and illuminate their talent in hopes that it spreads to other fans and media. We're not here to recycle the hype and cash in on ad revenue; instead, we're here to share our passion for music and help like-minded fans find their next favorite artist.Based out of Austin, Texas, GFG was created by long time music blogger AtxMonk. He has written for numerous independent publications since 2003 and continues to believe in creating media platforms that act as stepping stones for emerging bands and solo artists.

Happy is a Music Blog owned and run by music fans with one goal, to share great music with the world.Born in 2010, Happy started life as a community minded music festival. Created after a number of music venue closures, it turned non-music venues into band nights as a way to access emerging music. It saw great success with 20,000 event goers between 2010-2011.Since 2011, the Happy blog has been lovingly nurtured and is rapidly growing, expanding to a team of twelve contributors posting twenty four new articles a week. The Happy team are a dedicated bunch of music obsessives who only write about the music they love
Nothing you've heard before, but everything you want to hear

A blog about great music, if you'd like me to listen to your band or you just want to give me free shit e-mail me at happydaysmusicblog@yahoo.co.uk, ideally music to be sent rather than just links to soundcloud as i struggle with time to do this a lot as it is.

For the best chance of getting your material posted, please personalize the email, include a streaming link to the song or video, social media links, attach artwork/photo, and any other helpful information.

Harder Blogger Faster is a electronic music blog based in Manchester _éç it was started in June 2009 by freelance journalist Andrew Rafter, and has contributors across the world including Bristol, Dublin, LA, London, Manchester and San Francisco.Through a constant stream of news, reviews, features, track giveaways, interviews and competitions HBF has garnered a loyal following of the most up-to-date and music savvy readers online

Harmony Hungry is full of bite-size indie / alternative / folk / genreless music reviews with album reviews every Wednesday, Track of the Week on Friday and a rotation of Top 5s, Covers, Playlists and Classical Picks on Sunday. I won't say that I know everything about every record that's ever been released, that's impossible. I'm forever discovering new old things (or old new things) that have been around for ages, but have only just graced my ears. This is a journal of sorts, to document what I'm listening to, my thoughts and hopefully at least one of you will come away feeling glad that you visited today. I'm aware that reviews are completely subjective, so I concentrate more on being succinct, well-rounded and informative. Here you will find my own opinion, no one else's, and I encourage you to not take my word for it, create your own opinion. Take what you like, leave what you don't, it's all up to you
Finding for you the latest news in technology and the arts. If you want your product, or brand to be featured on here please send me details

Heathen Harvest offers the only true international perspective on our thriving underground music scene. With a collective of journalists culled from a number of countries including the USA, U.K., Russia, Netherlands, Sweden, Greece and Columbia we offer the most diverse perspective present on the internet. Heathen Harvest_éìs talented international collective of journalists and contributors offer informative reviews that go beyond the basics and delve deeply into descriptions and impressions of the music being reviewed. Our reviews offer the reader essential background information concerning the artists and inform the reader of relevant influences, inspirations, and references found within the music via off site web links. In addition to our review offerings our interview archive remains unrivaled in terms of content and professionalism. Our journalists explore beyond the customary interview questions seeking answers to questions no others ask.

Heavy Blog (Is Heavy) is a blog dedicated to heavy music and all its friends, featuring metal news, reviews, interviews, and other nincompoopery

GENRE: Heavy Metal / Death Metal / Thrash / Stoner Rock / Psychedelic
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Hi! My name is Reg Rykaczewski and I am the owner/main editor of Heavy Planet. Heavy Planet was actually established in 1999 as the internet was starting to explode and bands started to gain a web presence. I thought that it would be a cool way to start and promote bands through a streamlined website broken down into regions. I asked bands to send in their websites and the response was sparse, so I went on a hiatus for a few years. In 2006, I lost my job at a major music retailer and during my time off I decided to resurrect Heavy Planet as an outlet for people to to hear new Heavy Metal, Death Metal, Thrash Metal, etc. bands and get news, reviews, etc. I always had a passion for music and had many friends in bands that struggled to get their music heard. Some of my favorite bands include Black Sabbath, Kyuss, Fu Manchu, Monster Magnet, etc. so I decided to reformat Heavy Planet into a Stoner Rock Blog. My intentions always were to promote independent and local bands and on February 5, 2008. the new Heavy Planet format was born. The one feature that I am the most proud of is the "New Band To Burn One To", in which bands from all around the world send in their music and I feature it on the blog for the world to hear.

DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Hi! My name is Reg Rykaczewski and I am the owner/main editor of Heavy Planet. Heavy Planet was actually established in 1999 as the internet was starting to explode and bands started to gain a web presence. I thought that it would be a cool way to start and promote bands through a streamlined website broken down into regions. I asked bands to send in their websites and the response was sparse, so I went on a hiatus for a few years. In 2006, I lost my job at a major music retailer and during my time off I decided to resurrect Heavy Planet as an outlet for people to to hear new Heavy Metal, Death Metal, Thrash Metal, etc. bands and get news, reviews, etc. I always had a passion for music and had many friends in bands that struggled to get their music heard. Some of my favorite bands include Black Sabbath, Kyuss, Fu Manchu, Monster Magnet, etc. so I decided to reformat Heavy Planet into a Stoner Rock Blog. My intentions always were to promote independent and local bands and on February 5, 2008. the new Heavy Planet format was born. The one feature that I am the most proud of is the "New Band To Burn One To", in which bands from all around the world send in their music and I feature it on the blog for the world to hear.

Welcome to The Brand New and Improved Cool Breezy!  I am your loving host, Casey, aka _é£@stoopgirl from The Internet_éó aka Lil_éì Hot Wings aka Yung Egg White Delight. Here_éìs the rub:  Cool Breezy started in the very beginning of 2011 as something to keep me occupied while I was between jobs.  I_éìve always considered myself a writer in some way and have always desired to start a blog. After heeding some timely advice (_é£Just do something_éó) from a dear friend, I got to work and started sharing the things I loved with anybody who cared to read about them. Hooting And Howling Magazine is an online music magazine based in the UK, with writers in the UK, US, Europe and Australia.It was set up in February 2011 by Charlotte Davies, with the aim to introduce the most exciting music to the world. Since then, Hooting And Howling has since expanded the team across the world and has produced masses of content for our ever-growing audience. It has also become a platform for budding journalists of the highest quality who are looking for opportunities to express their thoughts and feelings about the music they love. Hooting And Howling strives to find the most exciting new music and the best new acts in the world.

iheardin started out as a way for two friends to keep their minds off of the stock market while day trading. After a month of writing about financial news and reviewing company statements the boys realized they might as well shoot themselves in the face because nothing could be more boring. One night of heavy drinking later and the site changed to incorporate interests outside of finance. From that summer night in august 2011, the dream of an online culture magazine featuring the best in music, art, film, books, and food was born. While we have an idea of what we_éìd like the site to be like, it has changed a lot since it started and continues to grow into a life of its own. Our team keeps growing and we keep tapping into more than we_éìve ever imagined. Stay tuned and take notice, we_éìre changing the game.watch cool new flicks and shows.embrace the entertainment.

_é£Curators of Pop Culture_éóComprised of musicians, writers, graphic designers, promoters and filmmakers, IHEARTCOMIX understands culture and has influenced it in Los Angeles and beyond for over 10 years. Music is alive but the industry is dying. Current trends in the music industry are making it impossible for bands to survive and a less desirable market for designers to enter. This recession is creating an opportunity to be at the forefront of a major change in the music scene. My goal is to shift the music industry to favor independent musicians and put more control and money back in their hands. I hope to shine some light on the positive changes happening in the industry and develop solutions for some of the existing problems.It is designed to serve three purposes:1. To create a space for people involved in the local music scene to post their thoughts/vents/what-have-yous outside of the usual venue of their band/company blog and give them an opportunity to represent themselves personally.2. To raise awareness and bring further community and cohesion to the local music scene.3. To further remove the middle man and give you a way to interact with these people a little more directly and, hopefully, personally!

...a digital director and former New Yorker by way of Chicago who is now living in in a pink building in the Mission neighborhood of San Francisco, CA.I enjoy music (obviously), nail polish, crock pots, my dvr, stinky cheese, nora ephron, bacon and french bulldogs. i do not enjoy pearl jam, people who eat food in the locker room at the gym, cankles, zooey deschanel and other things that are not awesome.for the past ten years i wrote a music blog about being young, vaguely employed, semi-intoxicated on vodka sodas and having a great time on the lower east side of manhattan and in brooklyn discovering new music. I spent some time working in the music industry, particularly a major label and have some weird stories about that. now that I'm a bit older my interests have "evolved" into a combination of the aforementioned with a little more "on my couch in sweatpants with a glass of pinot and Nashville on DVR" than before. join me as i talk about things that will still include music.. and then some.

DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Igloo Magazine is an electronic music e_éìzine publishing articles about current, classic and upcoming music from around the globe. Our mission is to introduce readers to the burgeoning undergrowth of electronic musicians by covering a wide range of genres including ambient, experimental, dub, dubstep, shoegaze, electro, techno, drone, IDM, industrial, post-industrial, and all the debris in between. I am a music freak and I love a good song regardless of genre attachments and specifications. A good song is a good song, plain and simple. I run Indie Vision Music not to make money, get rich, or look _é£cool_éó. I do it because of my love for music, my love for God, and for sharing hopeful music among a growing community of believers. I created the blog portion of ISO50 so I_éìd have a chance to share my influences and the things that inspire me. Over the years I have collected a lot of amazing examples of design and I will be posting the choice specimens here with my commentary. I am no idealogue, and certainly not an intellectual when it comes to design. I hold no college degrees and have never studied design. I have, however, independently practiced graphic design for almost ten years and at this point I feel I have a good grasp of what types of design I enjoy and what styles inform my own work. Obviously I do a good deal of looking back when it comes to inspiration. I feel the design that blossomed from the Bauhaus movement and came of age in the 1960_é_s was the Zenith of an art form whose importance would fade away as Television, and later the Internet, took over the reigns of visual communication thus effectively transforming the medium.

Founded in Madison in 2005, Jonk Music is a daily source for new music. As a University of Wisconsin student (now alumnus) and lover of all things indie music, Jon Kjarsgaard set out to create a site that covered both local and national bands from a grounded perspective. Diligent postings including _é£a new song daily,_éó summer mixtapes, and nuanced year-end lists led to increased readership and, in 2012, Jonk Music introduced a Madison page to its lineup. The Madison section originated from an interest not only in covering local and national releases but in expanding to feature local concerts as well. Since then, Jonk Music has interviewed numerous visiting acts including Animal Collective, Delta Spirit, Dirty Projectors, Local Natives, and Andrew W.K. Through dedicated team members and creative leadership, the site has grown steadily but the core idea remains: Madison is an awesome place for independent music and its scene deserves meticulous, tasteful coverage.

DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: We love Philly, pure and simple. And we love music. We_éìre tired of watching our local talent run off to New York or London to be appreciated.We_éìre here to blow up the music scene and shed light on all the amazing things that are happening here.In our quarterly print magazine, we cover Philly bands, venues, studios, history, bouncers, stylists, producers, clubs, boutiques, restaurants, deejays, music shops, record stores, labels, promoters, artists and anything else that has a connection to music in the city.We document all genres, from hip-hop and indie rock to classical, folk, jam bands, reggae, electronic, jazz and hardcore. We report on everything from street performers to the Philadelphia Orchestra.We are not part of a massive corporation. We are music-lovers. We go to concerts, dance in illegal basement venues, party at clubs, hang with other music-lovers and listen to lots of music. We are all a part of the Philly music scene in some way or another.

Lipstick disco was born from an observation, a realization that while there are a handful of heavyweight girls out there doing us proud, the music industry is still a very male dominated arena. Specifically in the field of House and Disco, the majority of DJ_éìs, producers, engineers, promoters etc are all guys. Lipstick Disco is here to represent the girls, not in a feminist kinda way, they_éìll be no bras burning, we just wanna put our lipstick mark on the collar of the house and disco boys...........Lipstick Disco isn_éìt just a music blog It_éìs a rummage through a crate of vinyl at a car boot sale to find that rare treat. Listen Local First DC (LLF) is a local music initiative devoted to building awareness and creating opportunities for local musicians and venues in order to raise the profile of DC's local music scene. LLF was born out of a collaborative effort with Think Local First DC and seeks to partner with local musicians, local arts organizations, local venues and locally owned businesses to create performance opportunities and new avenues for local music exploration. LLF's mission is not genre specific. In order to promote the true cultural depth of DC's music scene LLF would seek to equally represent all local genres, from folk to funk. Enjoy!

DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Local Music Nation is a website dedicated to the local music scene in San Diego and Los Angeles. Don_éìt mistake us for those indie snobs though. We love bands big and small from the local band to the major touring band. We love it all.

You may notice that the way we do things is a little different than other music blogs. We let our voices, our personalities and our experiences shine through. We might not hold back in telling you about that time we listened to Dark Side of the Moon twelve times back in high school. We like to get to know you, so we hope you_éìll enjoy getting to know us in return. We also hope you_éìll notice we take great care in the posts we feature on the site. We value thoughtful words, proofreading and other arts often lost in the haze of the internet _éç and we value these things as music as the music itself.Screen Shot 2014-10-19 at 9.57.40 PMLockeland Springsteen began as the brain child of music journalist Marissa R. Moss. Upon her move from Nashville from New York City, trading the Lower East Side for East Nashville, she was immediately struck by the depths of the musical talent here _éç and by the diverse, supportive community she found on her side of the Cumberland River. Soon, Lockeland Springsteen became the vessel through she could express her love for the city.Shortly after, Marissa met Emily, another New York to Nashville transplant, and they became a team. Katie, Kimberly and Shanning joined on in 2014.

Fabulously hailing from Kuwait, one of the world?s top music blogs (LOFT965.com) has been completely relaunched. To keep pace with increasing traffic and the ever-evolving blogosphere, the site has been completely revamped and recharged. The #1 music blog from the Middle East now boasts a fresh custom-made design, SEO optimization, exciting features and a whole new attitude. The blog has a list of contributors from all over the world.

This site is mainly about music. Now, most music blogs tend to be trying to find the next Arcade Fire/Grizzly Bear/Vampire Weekend/Furtive Chortle, and whilst that_éìs all well and good, I_éìve sometimes found it hard to find anything good about some of the older bands around. Not even necessarily particularly obscure bands. So that_éìs partly what this blog is about. And part of that is me listening to, and writing about, all the songs in The Pitchfork 500 list. Because it gives me a chance to listen to a pretty reasonable cross-section of pop/rock/indie/and a few other genres of the last 30-years

Manual Dexterity is a music zine that focuses on independently released bands, artists, and albums. Each issue tackles independent music from every angle, from interviews to album packaging and poster design to reviews.  Each issue features three in-depth interviews with up-and-coming and/or veteran bands, six quick shorter interviews with a variety of subjects (SIXES), a tour diary/journal of the ups and downs of life on the road (Transmissions), an in-depth look into the art of poster makers and the process behind the posters (SCRND), discussions with the graphic designers behind some of the more memorable album designs and packaging (A Sound Design), an occasional article and pages and pages of reviews.

This is a blog about one curmudgeon's love affair with the em dash, as told through ramblings on music and other cultural activities, mostly about things that happened in Toronto, Canada.This blog happens in real-life time, not internet time, so it's usually a good long while before full reviews of shows get posted. These days, because of, y'know, life, the gap between show and review is about a year. Think of this as more of an archival project than, like, breaking news, although exciting + notable recordings will still get posted pretty quickly after the fact.

After completing college, David went on to start an on-line Hip Hop magazine called Inkwell Media with his partners Benjamin DePoint and Jason Hammel. He interviewed up and coming and established artists like Broke, Little Brother, the legendary MC Shan, Ladybug Mecca of Digable Planets, Main Flow of Mood, Crisis Center and many others. After a successful four year run the magazine closed shop. He also has freelanced for Elemental Magazine, The Connex List and other publications and websites.David was in the Hip Hop group drop! with Benjamin, releasing the album, "Elements, Vibrations and Life Enzymes" and has performed his poetry on stages like The Nuyorican Poets Caf_∏ and the Bowery Poetry Club.Currently, David is working on his first novel, based on his childhood in Brooklyn.

METAL4AFRICA.com is a website intended to serve as a Global Gateway to African Metal.Even today, the world knows very little about the mysteries and myths regarding what has been traditionally called _é£The Dark Continent_éó by early explorers.  To a degree, Africa is still a _é£dark_éó continent, captivating many peoples imaginations and opening their minds to all sorts of fantasies.  In a modern world, this perception has served our (African) tourism industry very well, however, it does cripple other industries_éÙAfrica, like many regions around the globe, can celebrate a rich and diverse heavy metal sub-culture.  We have a history in metal spanning more than 2 decades, and a host of our own champions who tirelessly battle the odds to feed those who are hungry for heavy metal!  Regretfully, this is largely unknown to the rest of the world and our bands struggle forward in an under-developed industry, trying to find the light of day.  We hope that this website will honor those bands, as well as their supporters who come in the form of fans, friends, promoters and other businesses who have opened up windows of opportunity.

Metal as Fuck is a global metal lifestyle zine, and will soon be one of the world's leading communities of metal fans. It is a zine dedicated to lovers of metal in all its incarnations, and the primary destination for quality journalism and photography, exclusives you can't get anywhere else, and that inside view you never knew you wanted until you saw it here.This zine is Australia's #1 metal media. We have key contributors in strategic locations around the world, from Australia to Scandinavia, Europe to the US.We support the music industry from the ground up, providing a legitimate space for bands to promote themselves and their music, and build their own networks. But unlike every other zine out there, promoters, publicists, labels and other industry bodies are also given the opportunities to grab their own space, to post news that is circulated through the site immediately, and to get back in touch with the punters - wherever those punters happen to be.

The emphasis is on discovery: the discovery of new bands, new styles of music, and provocative opinion through insightful interviews with current bands. Propelled by a love of music, and a desire to give back on our own terms _éç Milk Crater was created to give music discovery a heart.We discover new music and share it with you. When you return the favor and share our golden nuggets of melody on social media, we make a small donation to charity.  That_éìs right, we make a donation for every single share. So let_éìs make the world a better place while bobbing our heads to Ringo Starr.Milk Crater adds a fresh twist to the traditional music blog.  In addition to serving up new discovery tracks daily, and publishing playlists for every occasion, we use music as a means to explore this crazy world we live in.  Sometimes we take ourselves seriously, sometimes we don_éìt. But we find life, in all of its many flavors, is a little bit better when set to a tune.

My love for music started on the road to the south of France on the backseat of parents car. I was 5 years old. Boxes filled with cassette tapes full of music. My father_éìs tapes. With The Beatles and 60_éìs music. Those of my big brother: the first grunge bands; Nirvana, Pearl Jam and Sonic Youth. And of course my own first tapes with Michael Jackson and Bruce Springsteen. Later on the walkman was replaced with a discman. My first cd_éìs; Dr. Dre, Mark Oh and Atlantic Ocean. True Dr. Dre I discovered hip hop. And hip hop made me discover soul and jazz. Through friends my collection got bigger with Led Zeppelin and The Doors. My exploration for _éïnew_éì music went like a time travel. From the 60_éìs to the 80_éìs and from the 70_éìs back to now. From electronic music to classical and from folk to indie music. Nowadays I'm lucky to combine this passion for music in my daily job as a studio & project manager at Amp.Amsterdam and managing the Dynamic Reflection and Soulfood record labels. Music is the heartbeat. _é£If you can talk, you can sing. If you can walk, you can dance._éó

It_éìs been over seven years now since we started mxdwn. In the beginning, it just simply felt like it had to be done. We had little more than aspirations and big dreams. Now, seven years later, it was time for a massive change. What you see here is mxdwn, redefined. This new presentation you_éìre looking at represents a philosophical simplification of all that we_éìve done in our history: to bring you the best in music news, reviews, concert coverage, photos and editorials, without the fluff that bogs down most music journalism. We hope that this new form helps you to better find and use mxdwn to discover all that matters in music.

Welcome to the My Kind Of Country blog. Here, you will find reviews, editorials, and discussions about the country music we love : our kind of country. The idea is simple: rather than write lots of negative reviews about the new music that_éìs coming out _éç because let_éìs face it, much of what comes out of Nashville and your country radio dial is crap _éç we are going to write about the music we love: the music that moves us, drives us, and makes us laugh and cry; the music that touches us. Not that we will spend our time writing about a select group of artists that are among our favorites. To the contrary, we intend to post about the music we love and tell you why we love it, and of course, how we think it could be improved upon.

My Spilt Milk is my website covering New Orleans' music and culture first and anything else that interests me second. I work from the premise that if I think something is interesting, someone else will too. As such, who and what I cover will reflect a genuine sensibility and not a triangulated space that no one actually inhabits. I've covered music, art, books and food in New Orleans since 1990. My work has appeared in The Times-Picayune, Gambit and most recently OffBeat, and I've freelanced for Spin, Rolling Stone, Essence, numerous alt-weeklies, Los Angeles Times, San Diego Union-Tribune, No Depression, Honest Tune and other places I can't remember now. These days I also conduct interviews at the Ogden Museum of Southern Art as part of its "Ogden After Hours" series.

Neil McCormick is a UK based music journalist. He has a weekly column in the Daily Telegraph, he is a regular guest on BBC Breakfast Television and an occasional expert on music industry matters for BBC News. He is also a sought after pundit on radio, contributing to shows on BBC Radio 3, 4, 5 Live, Scotland, Wales and The World Service. He was formerly Editor At Large at GQ and has contributed to many other publications including Marie Claire, Q Magazine, Hot Press, the Observer, the Sunday Times and the Irish Independent. In another life Neil was allegedly the first person to leave rock band U2.

We are alive and ready to inform those who may give a shit about relevant music related happenings that pertain the great city of Louisville.. Thanks for stopping by to join us here at Never Nervous. Over time Phil brought in Syd Bishop, a local writer, musician, and lover of comic books as a contributor. These two heroes write about all things Louisville and Louisville-centric, as those things intersect with Louisville music. The blog is updated on a regular basis, and includes but is not limited to band interviews, music reviews, news articles, and the occasional editorial. Yep, I_éìm New Music Michael _éç from Edmonton (the Alberta one). Though obviously most people don_éìt call me that. Most call me Michael. Some call me Mike. If they don_éìt know me from a hole in the ground, they_éìll refer to me as Michael Senchuk. I started writing this music blog a couple years ago purely as a response to friends and family who were regularly asking me for bands to check out. In fact, the tipping point was scribbling a few band names down for my hairstylist. It_éìs always been like that, back to the start of the grunge/alternative movement, following bands like Nirvana and Soundgarden, but with an eclectic taste that also included more folk-ey bands like Blue Rodeo and Crash Vegas, and even harder sounds like Vancouver_éìs Sons Of Freedom. Along the way I_éìve met some amazing people, musicians, other bloggers and music writers, promoters and venue managers. Oh, and press people, there_éìs some really awesome PR-ers out there.My day job finds me in a financial role, working on forecasts, budgets, accounting and reporting, and various special projects which sometimes I can_éìt even tell my wife about. Which is pretty cool, although it drives my wife a little bonkers at time. But then again, what husband doesn_éìt drive their wife a little bonkers from time to time.

GENRE: Country / Rock / Blues, Metal / Folk / Bluegrass
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Founded in September of 2006 by Bryan Childs under the moniker _é£Autopsy IV_éó and handed over to Mark Potter as _é£Romeo Sid Vicious_éó in January 2104, 9 Bullets is simply a website about music and the people that make it or support those making it. We don_éìt aspire to anything else and I, Romeo Sid Vicious, hope we never do. All of the writers here do what they do out of love and passion and not a single one of us makes a dime off of this place. To us this about getting the music we love to the ears of the most people possible and as such there isn_éìt a need to write scathing reviews. Sites like Saving Country Music and Pitchfork have the snark and nastiness covered well enough that there_éìs no reason for us to add to that. Simply put, we don_éìt have time to listen to bad music so why should we waste time trying to write about it?What does this mean to you, our faithful readers? It means that you can be assured that each article we write has been considered and thought through before being written. We may not always be up to the minute on new music we also don_éìt write reviews based on a couple of tracks from a promo email. We_éìd rather be a month behind other sites and be writing about something the makes us feel passionate than spew out content that_éìs not up to par. We are connected to a lot of the bands we write about on a personal level and call some of the artists friends and as such there may be a time where we do offer criticism but when and if that happens it will be out of our love for the artist and not spite.
