DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Founded in September of 2006 by Bryan Childs under the moniker _é£Autopsy IV_éó and handed over to Mark Potter as _é£Romeo Sid Vicious_éó in January 2104, 9 Bullets is simply a website about music and the people that make it or support those making it. We don_éìt aspire to anything else and I, Romeo Sid Vicious, hope we never do. All of the writers here do what they do out of love and passion and not a single one of us makes a dime off of this place. To us this about getting the music we love to the ears of the most people possible and as such there isn_éìt a need to write scathing reviews. Sites like Saving Country Music and Pitchfork have the snark and nastiness covered well enough that there_éìs no reason for us to add to that. Simply put, we don_éìt have time to listen to bad music so why should we waste time trying to write about it?What does this mean to you, our faithful readers? It means that you can be assured that each article we write has been considered and thought through before being written. We may not always be up to the minute on new music we also don_éìt write reviews based on a couple of tracks from a promo email. We_éìd rather be a month behind other sites and be writing about something the makes us feel passionate than spew out content that_éìs not up to par. We are connected to a lot of the bands we write about on a personal level and call some of the artists friends and as such there may be a time where we do offer criticism but when and if that happens it will be out of our love for the artist and not spite.

This is a labor of love, sometimes a labor of lust. We could make money if we wanted to, probably enough to buy an extra shot or something oily and caffeinated the next morning, but we don_éìt advertise and we don_éìt take money from anyone else for anything. Life is already too cluttered.We_éìve been around since November 2009. When the site began, the name of it was serious. But as time has passed, my own tastes have broadened and other writers have joined us, and they_éìre even more open-minded than I am. Now, the name just confuses people, because sometimes we write about metal that includes actual singing instead of (or in addition to) growling, howling, and shrieking. But it_éìs kind of like if you named your kid Rufus. When she grows up, it confuses other people, but she is what she is and it might confuse people even more if you legally changed it.So, we write about lots of music genres, 99% of it metal, and about 99% of that extreme metal. We call it like we see it, even when we_éìre cross-eyed. But we only write about music we like and want to recommend. If we don_éìt like something we just ignore it. If you_éìre looking for negative reviews, you_éìll need to go elsewhere.

I_éìm constantly on the prowl for the next new artist and audio masterpiece; that quintessential album you crave and can_éìt stop listening to. The one that gets better with each listen and doesn_éìt fade. I imagine it_éìs a similar experience a junkie might have looking for their next fix. There_éìs the anxiety and tension that builds from the search until finally the craving is satisfied with the sweet relief of a score. That_éìs me, but music is my crack.Mostly, I_éìm indie rock girl, but I have been known to occasionally dabble in a little electronica. I was born and raised in Dayton, OH and cut my teeth on WOXY in Cincinnati (now based in Austin, TX). To my indie rock roots I stand true. In fact, WOXY is still one of only three terrestrial radio stations I_éìll even consider listening to today. (KEXP and KCRW are the other two.)

Reviewing every band on the SXSW lineup since 2010....That_éìs where we come in.  Among those 2,000 artists are the next _éïbuzz bands of 2014_éì, but more importantly, artists that will fit directly in your tastes and should move into your record collection.  For Operation Every Band, the goal is to listen and review every artist on the roster.  For anyone who cares to do the math, that_éìs a lot of listening and writing, but the payoff is exponential with sounds from the past, present and future.  Over the next five months, the OEB team (Kevin, Alison, Nate and Lucas) will be posting write-ups, videos, a slew of artist interviews and other SXSW goodies.  Our bread and butter comes with The Spreadsheet, an all-encompassing look at the SXSW roster with descriptions and micro-reviews along with our subjective rating.  I_éìll follow up with a series of posts detailing out the process and what to expect for this year_éìs OEB season over the next week, but above all, it_éìs great to be back!

Welcome to PICKSYSTICKS, a blog site that spotlights the best indie bands in Los Angeles - they just happen to be fronted by women! Unlike their counterparts, these chick bands shell out a different feel and sound that only these gals can emote. But, through the music, what separates girl bands is that they also have the ability to let us hear their vulnerability and show us their passion. Whether it be punk, acoustic, rock, or electronica, in a diverse city such as Los Angeles, you can find anything to please your musical tastes on any given night. If your cup of tea are girl bands then PICKSYSTICKS is the place to be. Check out these bands and you_éìll realize, through this _éïangelic hard-rock,_éì why L.A. is called the City of Angels.

GENRE: Pop / Indie / Alt / Hip Hop / Rock
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Popology Now is, loosely, the study of pop music. The way it makes you feel. The way you react to it. The way it_éìs composition can produce one of the biggest hits of the year_éÙor one of the most underwhelming songs that we forget about. It_éìs all of those things and more. It_éìs a passion, it_éìs a belief, it_éìs a lifestyle.Popology Now firmly believes that in 2014 and beyond, anything can be pop music. Mainstream, indie, alternative, rap, rock, hip-hop, R&B, soul. It is all pop music here. There is no _é£paint by numbers_éó formula, there is no foolproof map to follow. Well, there is, but it_éìs that style that tends to burn out quicker than it appeared. That_éìs why you will see all of those genres on this site because, for us, it pops and it IS pop.

Raised by Gypsies was formed as a way to promote music which is free for listeners to download, usually from Band Camp. There is quite a bit of free music out there for your ears, but free download doesn't always mean it's good. RBG is a way to help you guide your way through what to download. Basically, our reviews say (for the most part) "This is a great album and you can download it for free so you should".We also really like cassettes and physical forms of music which can be purchased to help support artists. While we have always had the theory of music being best when it is free, listening to something without paying for it is not going to help anyone and if you want the bands you like to continue to make music then you should grab a cassette, t-shirt, see them live, whatever. Just give your money to bands you like or else they might no longer be there.

If you're playing in a band and want to see your music featured on our blog - send a download link of your demo to the address mentioned above (rabmblog [AT] gmail [DOT] com). Note: you can also use hayduke495 [AT] gmail [DOT] com, if you're playing green anarchist (especially Cascadian) BM; blackened grindcore/crust is OK too.Make sure to include the following information:- band name, release name/year, country of origin, album cover image (or at least band photo or logo);- track listing (properly numbered);- preferably a full release (not samples or streaming) in mp3/m4a/ogg (128kbps or higher bitrate). You may use any free filesharing site (preferably Mediafire) to host your files; or you can use Bandcamp (but then make sure your release is available for free download). *** NO LARGE ATTACHMENTS PLEASE!!! ***;- any other info about you and your release (links to any sites related to your band, release notes, etc.);- reason why you want your music to be featured on our blog (note that it's not just another metal blog, and even if your band is apolitical, it still should be somehow in the spirit of RABM movement)

Thank you for visiting Rollo & Grady. We_éìre an online music publication and music supervision, licensing, management, and production company based in Los Angeles. Our goal is to provide a convenient and efficient way to discover and rediscover quality music. We_éìre excited to share the music that we listen to. At Rollo & Grady, you_éìll find tracks from the past, the present, and everywhere in between, as well as local and national music news, reviews, music videos, and interviews.Rollo & Grady Productions focuses on placing up-and-coming indie artists in film, television, commercials, video games and online advertisements. We_éìve served as music consultants for both film and television, working with Mike Barker, Matt Weitzman, and Seth Macfarlane on Season 5, 6, and currently on season 7 of the Fox program American Dad and with Fox Searchlight on the film Cedar Rapids, starring Ed Helms and John C. Reilly, directed by Miguel Arteta (Youth In Revolt, The Good Girl) and produced by Jim Burke and Alexander Payne (Election, Sideways). Room Thirteen launched in October 2003 and to this day is run entirely by volunteers who share a common passion for music and all that goes with it.We are a completely independent organisation that strives to provide as wide a coverage as possible with next to no resources. We think we do a pretty fine job at it and it seems Joe Public agrees; our monthly unique visitor numbers passed the 200,000 mark for the first time back in 2007.Since we first started we have worked with hundreds (if not thousands!) of labels and PR companies to provide coverage of thousands of releases and news items as well as features and interviews. We've interviewed everyone we could get our hands on from Motorhead to The Charlatans! We're as interested in the small guys breaking through as we are in the big guns and you're just as likely to find a review of a demo from an unknown band taking their first steps in the business as you are to find a review of Metallica's latest offering.

It was created as an outlet for sharing exceptional music. As we will soon be releasing our own material, the dual approach we have recently embraced allows us to develop our own distinct sound while showcasing the music that influences us on a daily basis. Above all, we remain strictly dedicated to receiving new artists, their projects and the ideas behind them. Through meticulous exploration we ensure that we are constantly progressing and pushing the limits of our expression.More than any particular style, the defining characteristic of the music you will find here is originality. From the darkest and deepest corners of the club to the brightest resonant highs, the creativity and audacity of each artist is paramount. What we can absolutely guarantee is that the work we are sharing with you has veritable meaning. Humans respond to feelings and we strongly believe that as well as being heard, music must also be felt; it must induce a reaction in people.Ultimately, our existence is dictated by our collective passion for music. With this boundless appreciation we will continue to release and share our favourite work for you to enjoy. Our story will continue to evolve and we sincerely hope you will be a part of it. We are excited to continue promoting talented and forward thinking producers and we look forward to an extraordinary fulfilling and enterprising future. Welcome to Room516.

GENRE: Metal / Hardcore / Jazz / Indie / Hip Hop / Pop / Alt
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Scene Point Blank is a music webzine founded in March 2003 by four individuals on the AFI messageboard. The site initially began with a focus on hardcore/punk but has since expanded in its seven-years-and-counting history to cover indie, hip-hop, pop, jazz and more.One of the site's early goals to set it apart from competitors was our "multiple author" reviewing concept. Several writers would tackle the same record and give individual scores which were then averaged out for the overall rating. This balanced effort at reviewing also carries over into the site's methods for forming "Best Of" lists at the end of the year - each staffer submits a list of their top records and this is compiled into an overall, democratically-selected site list - no editorialising.

DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Skin Back Alley is a site of music news, reviews and features. We aim to be inclusive and maintain integrity in all that we do. Mainstream pop is just as welcome as death metal.We_éìll always try to find something good to say about the music reaching our ears. And if we can_éìt find something good we_éìll tell you that, too. What we won_éìt do is offer personal prejudice wrapped in the cloak of critique.Launched in 2010, Skin Back Alley was so named because of a lane in the village of Whitwell, north east Derbyshire, where you used to be able to buy a rabbit for just two pence as long as you promised to return the skin. Hence Skin Back_éÙ.. The rabbit skin would be treated and sold on and every part of the animal was used in a meaningful way.

Sleaze rock is the bastard child of heavy metal, as the term defines a musical genre that has almost as much to do with attitude as songs. The music itself is rebellious, aggressive and downright nasty. The PMRC hated it, as did your parents. Whether it was Zodiac Mindwarp claiming to be the "Tattooed Beat Messiah," Spread Eagle getting "Back On The Bitch," L.A. Guns wanting some "Sex Action," or Rhino Bucket begging fans to "Ride The Rhino," the attitude remained the same as they gave the general public the middle finger.   Often sleaze bands came across better live then in a studio that tried to harness their aggression. They were at the top of their game when touring on the road, abusing drugs and alcohol and having sex with your daughters or wives. The look and attitude also separated them from other bands. Long hair that looks like it's been washed with used motorcycle oil, black leather jackets and tight pants, and tattoos proudly displayed from head to toe are all trademarks of a true sleaze band. They truly were the outlaws of rock 'n' roll.   As you can see, this site encompasses more than just sleaze. Similar underrated genres such as glam metal, album oriented rock, hair metal (and other silly terms such as mullet and cock rock), southern rock, heavy metal and simple hard rock are appreciated here. So sit back and discover some new groups, or just reminisce about your old 80's hard rock favorites.

As well as posting interviews and news, we also film acoustic or stripped down versions performed by bands that we love as they make their way through Boston. Though it started as something we did when bands needed a place to crash on the night of their shows, we now film the sessions before or after a show and let the bands find their own ways home.Basically, we try to use our spaces as creatively as we can.  We_éìve filmed in the back seats of cars, on top of playground equipment, in doorways and alleys, in bathtubs and stairwells.  We try our best to get the bands to take their music outside of the confines of the studio and have some fun.And that_éìs the point: to capture some great music that maybe isn_éìt always as polished, but shows these artists having a good time doing what they love. We_éìre doing what we love too, and hope you enjoy the videos!We at Sleepover Shows only post material that has been given to us freely by the bands we record, their management, or their PR firms for streaming on the internet.We claim no copyright to the songs, but we do claim ownership of the videos as well as the photography.Any advertising that appears on the site does not represent a sponsorship of any band or label.If you like what you see and hear, the best way to support the band is to go see their show or buy their album, so go support them!

Soul Motion started out as a small clubnight constantly moving in and around Bruges... Belgium. Soul Motion emerged out of a strong believe in the power of listening & dancing to good music. The Soul Motion dj's are deeply in love with music and the culture that surrounds it. They serve a sweet cocktail of open minded, powerfull groove, aimed at the head and the feet : .... funk, soul, dancefloor jazz, afro-latin grooves, brazilian vibes, pop music, bossa-, deep-, soul- and house, disco, boogie, salsa, latin... we try to expose quality music, no matter what individual sound or style is featured; in this process we are inspired by the sounds of the past, present and future... Soul Motion also evolved into a podcast on Itunes, a cloudcast on Soundcloud and the blog you are reading now.

Sound & Vision is a portal of appreciation and dissemination of alternative music; Here you will find a news center for all your favorite bands and these new proposals that do not yet know. We like to share and anticipate what is happening on the global scene and be updated on the most important releases of time exploring and discovering new sounds and remember the events that have marked the timeline in the sound universe. In our world, what matters most is the music, so we provide coverage no matter the country, city or language of origin, focusing only on their quality, thus promote the unification of local, national and international scenes. We invite you to be active and essential part of our community by sharing your opinion and passion for music with music lovers for which S & V was born, is and continues to grow:

24 year old Norwegian girl currently doing my graduate studies in Copenhagen, Denmark. I am very passionate about house, dance-pop, indie and electronica, and I like to keep myself updated on new songs in these genres especially. We live in an amazing era of music, there is so much to explored and enjoyed!I like to make long playlists that function as kind of a soundtrack in my life. In other words, I can listen to songs that define the present, and at a later point, those same songs will remind me of memories, moods and feelings from the past. I love the idea that music can define a certain time in life, like a soundtrack.

Sounds and Colours is a magazine about South American music and culture. Through regular articles, news, reviews and audiovisual features we focus on the diverse cultures of the South American continent with music, film and the arts at the core of what we do.     Sounds and Colours began in order to promote South American music and culture. We felt that Latin American culture was often shown through a narrow lens, missing much of the diversity that makes it such a rich culture. Our aim from day one has been to show all sides of South American culture, especially those that have been under-represented in the past.

Music fans, not critics, this is a place for the Spectral Nights team to wax lyrical about bands we like and gigs we_éìve been to _éç from album reviews to new music videos and much more besides, including the occasional interview, festival review and band playlist, we mainly focus on alternative music, but have a fond love of pop music and will endlessly quote High Fidelity.

Spectrum Culture arose from the need for a website that reviews music and films. Well, not really. There are millions out there. But, I am fairly certain we are the first to include a food section with music and film coverage. Why food? It seems these days that all film and music snobs are also food connoisseurs in their own right.Rather than be news-driven like many of the major webzines, Spectrum Culture will devote itself to features and reviews. Our readers will expect great writing that is both intellectual and irreverent. Instead of hell-bent, indie-only coverage, our writers are allowed to explore whatever interests them. If someone wants to explore the newest High School Musical film, fine! As long as the review is thoughtful and intelligent, we feel our readers will appreciate it. Call us an indie site with big aspirations.

GENRE: Indie / Alt / All / EDM / Electronic / Hip Hop
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Stereogum.com was one of the first MP3 blogs and remains the leading online community for independent and alternative music news, downloads, and videos. Its audience includes passionate music fans, industry folks, and household names like Kanye West, Ben Gibbard, and Ryan Adams. Stereogum regularly features unknown artists who go on to become mainstream sensations such as Vampire Weekend, Arcade Fire, and Fleet Foxes. Cited for its commentary and band discovery everywhere from The New Yorker to FOX News, Stereogum_éìs awards and distinguished mentions include the Plug Award for best music blog, Blender_éïs Most Influential People in Online Music, Village Voice_éïs Music Blog Of The Year, and Entertainment Weekly_éïs Best Music Website.

Striker Bill is a web-based music publication offering glimpses and reviews of a wide variety of artists and bands new and old, obvious and obscure.Company OverviewStriker Bill is a web-based music publication centered around an entirely unique and occasionally controversial system of reviewing newly released albums. Whereas most criticism outlets will write a bunch of nonsense and slap a seemingly random, meaningless number or a bunch of stars on an album, the Striker Bill score represents the actual percentage of an album that is worth the listener's time. New reviews are published daily featuring a wide variety of artists from the obvious to the obscure. Also in the mix is our revolving and growing collection of features, which includes the ever popular weekly song discussion known as The Jury. Plus, daily Quick Strikes offer quick glances at a variety of cool bands and provide free and legal mp3 downloads and streams.

Sunken Sounds is a new media publications blog/editorial; we aim to aggregate the most recent in many different genres including (but not limited to) hip-hop, Rnb/Soul, electronic music, indie rock, etc.We have a passion for quality in spirit as far as music goes, and our diverse team of track selectors is always keeping a finger to the pulse of current releases, both DIY and studio.To those that are interested in being featured, please forward all submissions to sunkensounds@gmail.com with the following formatting:Subject: [Label] Artist name _éç Release name (Year)We have literally thousands of emails sitting in our inbox waiting to be read, so I_éìm sorry if we don_éìt respond immediately. Show support for our website by following us and hit us up on Twitter in the meantime. These alerts will get sent direct via mobile. Spammy tweets will probably be ignored.@musicunderwater on Twitter.DescriptionSometimes we put on shows. Sometimes we take photos. Sometimes we design posters. Sometimes we just post mp3's and videos for you to enjoy. Pretty good deal, huh?

I will do my best to listen to as much music sent in as possible but please note that I do not do regular features or reviews of upcoming music; instead, this blog focuses more on the business of the Music Industry and tips for upcoming bands and artists looking to get ahead within it

Sunset in the Rearview is a music blog started in December 2008 that features mainly indie-rock and hip-hop. We also feature mashups and some electronic tunes. Some days, though, all we want is some softer folk music. No matter what the genre, we_éìll provide you with new music every day and typically some fun reading to go along with it.Sunset was founded by Lydia Simmons in 2008. It started simply as a way to share great music, but has evolved into a collection of new music, reviews, interviews, news, and more. It_éìs different from the thousands of other music blogs in that it_éìs not racing to post the newest music first; we serve as a bit of a filter. We give the music a good listen before posting it, making sure that we can say something worth your time reading when we do end up posting it.  5000 likes of FB  Music Submissions (with cover art) should be sent to the following:                                                                                                   Music Submissions are accepted in SoundCloud messages[Link to our SoundCloud page] Please let us know in the message if you would like for us to consider premiering your track.music@sunsetintherearview.com*The preferred format is to include a direct file.mp3 link in the email or a link to a SoundCloud player. If you are interested in promotional giveaways, please specify this in the subject line. Thank you!

This was the name of a weekly Radio Show in 2004/2005 on Twen.FM hosted by BarbNerdy. It was a former pirate radio station which went digital at this time here in Berlin. Crazy music, it was the time 2step was the shit and it was the only radio you could listen to this music in Berlin.  I had a lot of fun playing my fave tunes and DJ_éìs from around the world who were currently in Berlin where regular guests. Plus all these great musicians living just around the corner and the regular visitors from all over the world. Unforgetable the outstanding show with Blake Baxter and Abe Duque or with the Stones Throw Dudes.  Some recordings of this shows must still be in the interwebs. Will try to find and publish them here.  nothing found. In 2011 _é£support your local ghetto_éó  became the name of a monthly event at the wonderful Panke, (Artspace) in Berlin/Wedding. The concept is the same, just playing eclectic music like Bass, Footwork, Juke, Grime, Garage, Electronics, cool HipHop and Beatz but also a place for the sadest songs on earth". This fits perfect with the wonderful, openminded audience aka all the DancerCrews.

GENRE: Indie / Electronic / Alt / Hip Hop / Dance / EDM
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Surviving the Golden Age was started in 2005 on Blogger. Built from the ground up, it became one of the most read music blogs on the internet (sort of). In February of 2010, the blog was deleted by Blogger upon pressure from the DMCA. Several days later this incarnation of Surviving the Golden Age was launched, Surviving the Golden Age 2: Electric Bugaloo as we liked to call it. Enjoy the fruits of our labour.If you want to contact us email Adam at Surviving the Golden Age dot com.The best way to submit music to be considered for posting is to email the above email address with an mp3 or soundcloud link. The email should also contain some flattering comments towards how awesome Surviving the Golden Age is or how handsome is its creator.Submissions will not be accepted via Surviving the Golden Age_éìs twitter, facebook, or soundcloud pages. Submissions through social media will be banned from posting consideration. Submissions will also not be accepted if your main website is a Myspace page because this is not 2003_éÙMark Zuckerberg won_éÙjust watch the Social Network.Thanks for reading!

Swan Fungus hated Arcade Fire first.MissionTo fuck Gail Simmons. In the ass.Company OverviewThis page began as a reflexive exercise aimed at exploring the creative process of one of the world_éìs foremost unenlightened thinkers. It has since become something of an electronic watering hole where folks from around the world gather to hear the rantings of a bored and depraved individual. You could even call it a modern Beer Hall Putsch.The esteemed online music retailer eMusic once referred to Swan Fungus as _é£the most self-centered blog on the Internet._éó In an era where everybody blogs, that is a bold declaration.Recommended If You Like: biting social commentary, apolitical discourse, non-conformity and low-brow humor.

Swirls of Noise is a music website featuring album and live reviews, interviews and a weekly radio.The main ethos of the website is to share good music from a variety of different genres with the focus of bringing talented yet not very well known artists to more people_éìs attention _éç though covering fantastic music by better known artists too.My own favourite genres include: metal, ambient, drone, grindcore and shoegaze. That said I_éìm open to absolutely anything that_éìs good, and feel free to let me know about any music of any genre.I write album/single/demo reviews, as well as live reviews and interviews. For any requests please contact me either via any of the contact methods below. Digital or physical submissions are both fine. Unfortunately due to time constraints I don_éìt have time to review anything, but every submission is considered for review or radio.

SYFFAL.com started out as a group of friends emailing their music finds to one another, with clever little write ups that eschewed the traditional album review format. We eventually realized that we were on to something and decided to take the show on the road. We started SYFFAL as a way to share our love for the music that moved us, and connect artists we loved with people beyond our small group. Our approach to music is this: If we like it, we ride for it. If we don't? Fuck it. We are not going to listen to it another 6 times and then spend an hour or so writing a piece explaining why it sucks. That is something only a cutter or a sadomasochist would do.Instead we focus on the positive, not in a "The Secret" way but in a "This makes me want to take acid in the shower while eating a falafel kind of way". You won't find over thought reviews, you won't find self important interviews. You will find a small band of music fans talking about music the way fans talk about music, fuck all that other pretty boy shit. Indie Music, Album Reviews, Band Interviews Looking for new music SYFFAL IT Independent Music, Album Reviews, Interviews & best of all, Del in a tank top, rocking a mustache, looking down his nose at you

Well, the short version is that it_éìs my silly attempt to be quirky and hip and still be clear that we_éìre talking about music here.  Audio.  Sound.  Music.I started this blog in February 2010 as a place to house lists of songs around a theme (rain, Scottish artists, morning, breaking up, etc.) that I was posting on Twitter.  Soon enough I started wanting people to read what I wrote, and the rest is history.Think of this blog as a musical journal, with a focus on music supervision and a goal of sharing great music in new ways.  Songs as they relates to an experience, a memory, a sensation, a journey, a great meal.  Artists as they relate to other artists, media you have heard (or should hear) them in.  I hope to explore all the ways people use music to tell their own tales.  From brilliant songwriters to up and coming artists, experienced music supervisors, music bloggers, DJs, and everything in between, everyone connects to music differently _éç different genres, mediums, purposes, emotions.

We are an extreme music entertainment website, focusing on album reviews, blogs, interviews, news, and community. Basically, we_éìre not re-inventing the wheel. Amped is a blog project created by Ryan Pressman, a student and musician, in an effort to facilitate the spread of information on guitars, guitar gear, and music. Due to the ever-changing technology in the world of guitars and music, Ryan wanted to create a medium that relates the technical aspects of music to the context in which it appears, and thus, Amped was born. As a guitar and music-oriented blog, Amped makes it its mission to study the critical aspects of how guitar and music technology is being applied in both a live and studio setting from artist to artist, whilst keeping an account of the artistic motivations behind its application as well. In order to accomplish this, Amped takes precautions to ensure accuracy and quality in its reports in order to cultivate and provide for a well-informed fan base. - See more at:

The Big Takeover is a bi-annual music magazine published out of New York City since 1980 by critic Jack Rabid, with the considerable help of dozens of staffers, interns, contributors, and volunteers. The Big Takeover usually appears in June and December, with most recent issues coming in around 200 glossy pages. The review section, featuring Jack_éìs Top 40 for the issue, is regularly 60-80 pages long. The magazine also features lengthy, in-depth interviews with favorite artists transcribed verbatim, sometimes stretching over two issues.The Big Takeover recently relocated to Brooklyn from the Lower East Side NYC apartment that was its home for 25 years, highlighted by its special 30th anniversary festival at Brooklyn_éìs Bell House club, July 30-31, 2010 (with The Chameleons_éì Mark Burgess, The Avengers, For Against, Springhouse, Channel 3, Visqueen, Sleepover Disaster, The Sharp Things, Don McGlashan of Mutton Birds, Libertines U.S., Jon Auer of The Posies, Steve Drewett of Newtown Neurotics, EDP, Flower, Paul Collins, and Curtain Society.

SUBMISSIONS*** IMPORTANT NOTE RE: SUBMISSIONS ***  Before writing to us regarding submissions, please note: the Daily Vault is an album review site.  That means we review ALBUMS.  Not singles, not individual tracks you've licensed for commercials, not your latest demos, not the partial tracks you posted on MySpace that you're going to finish mixing next week.  Whole, completed, released ALBUMS.  (And sometimes whole, completed, released EPs.  But no other exceptions.)  Inquiries regarding singles, demos, etc. will be ignored. Welcome to The Dinner Party Download, a fast and funny hour of culture, food and conversation; essentially, it_éìs _é£public radio_éìs arts & leisure section._éó In every episode you_éìll learn a joke_éÙ bone up on an odd bit of history and then wash it down with a themed cocktail recipe_éÙ meet artists of note (for instance Pharrell Williams, Scarlett Johansson, Steve Martin)_éÙ have your burning etiquette questions answered by the likes of Mel Brooks or Aisha Tyler_éÙ savor an emerging food trend_éÙ and hear your new favorite song. The Electricity Club was founded on 15th March 2010 in a bid to be part of the emerging electropop scene. Several meetings followed to discuss how best to become involved in this vibrant scene.These meetings were referenced in reports and subsequent meetings were arranged to discuss the outcome of the reports on the previous meetings. Some PowerPoint presentations were involved.The final conclusion was aim to feature the best in new and classic electro AND pop. With informed opinion and trivia, this site is for like-minded people who are excited about pop music and not afraid to try something new.Whether it_éìs the heroes of Synth Britannia, the new wave optimism of New Pop or the female-led L-Word electro generation, it all deserves your attention. A site that dares to mention LADY GAGA, LITTLE BOOTS, OMD, NEW ORDER and KRAFTWERK in the same breath? A site that likes to talk about the best of the new sounds that are emerging in an invigorated music scene? A site that prefers not to employ phrases such as _é£80s_éó?

In case you were wondering, my blog is named after the Boo Radleys song. I remember buying that single in Caen, France while I was going to university there for the semester back in_éÙwell, that doesn_éìt matter. The EP was called Every Heaven, and it came out on Rough Trade. Anyway, this blog is based in Seattle, USA. It_éìs mostly about music, but other things sneak in here and there. I originally started the thing to write about gigs, the problem is though I can never seem to get to see everything I would like to see. I_éìm always looking for reviews of the ones I miss, and appreciate it when somebody has taken the time to post a review of show they went to. So the original (and still current) intent was to fill in the gaps, you know, in case you may have missed your favorite band that played last night.

In 2007, a french electro duo altered minds and changed the world of music, revitalizing old school bass lines, resampling iconic tracks, and inducing madness on the dance floor. For us, they were not only innovators, but also collaborators and thinkers _éç you can_éìt argue with that. We_éìre here to revive that very same atmosphere, bringing french touch talent to light. The French Shuffle is a music blog dedicated to all things french house, electro, disco, and funk.Currently, the blog exists as a liaison between musicians and their respective listeners, keeping the audience up-to-date on artists, events, interviews, news, and more. Focusing on these specific genres, we_éìre seeking to revitalize the thrilling flavor of the 80s, 90s, and early 2000s french house movement.

NAME OF BLOG: The Good The Band The Unkown
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: The #1 place to get music lists on the internet. Where most lists go to ten, I'll do them one better and go to eleven. Some of the lists will be a "best of" (the good), some will be a "worst of" (the bad), and some lists will focus on unknown bands and music (the unknown). I've been a music blogger since 2006.  I started this site as a means to practice my writing.  Over time it became a place for music lovers to come and find out about music that they didn't know about that may have slipped by or to read about bands they loved.  I enjoy hearing from the people who disagree with my lists as much as I enjoy hearing from the people who completely agree with them.  As I writer, I have written for TV, movies, and magazines but have found writing a music blog the most rewarding of all.  It's the least perfect and the most human.

Started in January 2013 by two brothers, The Great Bambino is a online music blog with a splash of young culture added in. We know that the music is much more than what comes through your speakers- context is everything. So,  we_éìll bring the music and everything that comes with it. Enjoy!

The Indie SD is a music blog. A place where I get to spill all of my crazy escapades with back alleys, dim lit rooms, bright lights, busted eardrums and backstage passes. I want this site to be about more than just one person_éìs opinion on the latest albums. I want to share the experiences of shows, the opinions of the music scene, and the stories of the musicians behind all of this.It_éìs supposed to be a mixture of fun, thought-provoking and creative topics on music. But it_éìs also as much your site as it is mine. That means, your opinions matter, your thoughts count, and yes this will be on the final. If you ever have something to say about the music scene around you, consider The Indie SD your very own megaphone.Whether you_éìre a music lover here in San Diego or somewhere around the world, this site contains all the news, conversations, and stories of a busy & fascinating music scene. Let me know what you think about your music scene, your favorite musicans, or about this site.

The Indiependent_éì is a digital entertainment website that was born in July 2014. It came into being because I felt that many entertainment sites have walls, between the producers and the consumers of the articles contained within. I don_éìt like that sense of separation, with the musical elitism that surrounds popular music review sites especially...If you_éìre a musician looking for coverage then you_éìve come to the right place! We_éìre always keen to expose talented people to our audience so if you have singles, EPs or live dates that you_éìd like us to review

In an ever-evolving world, our relationship to new music is progressively becoming more and more like the rapid fire experience of casual sex: find a single, take it home and play with it for a few days before tiring and moving on to the next eligible single, never to call again.   We_éìre for taking that album home, getting to know the good (with the bad) and having those awkward conversations: What do you like? What don_éìt you like? What gets you off?   We know not all relationships are destined to work but by injecting time, dialogue and, most importantly, debate back into the way we experience music, you might actually find something you like amongst new and unfamiliar territory.   With an emphasis on collaborative conversation surrounding new music, we endeavour to bring you singles from all over the internet, with the hope that you_éìll sit with something, get to know it, get to know us and, who knows, maybe even find yourself a new life partner (or 10).

Bringing you the latest news and information from the world of jazz and beyond...

Jazz music reviews and news from Ian Mann the Jazz Mann.  Jazz is an ever-evolving music and I think it_éìs great that after listening to it for all this time the emergence of exciting young musicians still gives me a thrill. I think we have some fantastically talented players in this country, right across the generations but sadly many of them are deeply undervalued.If my work on this site helps in any way to gain greater recognition for new musicians I will be more than satisfied.Geographical isolation has meant that I_éìve not had many people to bounce ideas off or to be influenced by. Perhaps it is a good thing for a reviewer.

Since 2009 we have been extensively covering the new generation of rappers, opening up the genre to a whole new generation of fans. The Masked Gorilla was the first site solely dedicated to these new school freshman rappers, resulting in nearly 10,000 posts over the past 4 years.

So what can I tell you about myself? I am from Belfast. I enjoy writing about new music, which keeps me afloat. The Guardian once profiled this blog. I'm old enough to have experienced the Walkman without being retro, but not old enough to have used MySpace whilst it was still cool. I was nominated for the Sony Radio Golden Headphones Award in 2013. Caramacs and Battenberg are life affirming, and the moment some bright spark combines the two my life will be complete. And I don't own a captain's hat, largely because I suspect the hat shop will try to fob me off with a milkman's cap.   I am always on the lookout for fantastic new music that floats my metaphorical boat. If you know of any great music that I should be featuring, or are a maker of fine music yourself, then drop me an email.

NAME OF BLOG: The Modern Folk Music Of American (H)
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: the goal of my site is to feature what i think of as "folk music", which is music made by people who are trying to get by leading lives in our modern world who love to express themselves through music. any genre or medium is welcome. i prefer submissions via soundcloud, bandcamp, or youtube, because these formats allow me to easily embed your music in my post and it leads readers directly back to your site, video stream, etc.my site is unlike many music sites because i do not select or review the music i post. i post what is sent my way or occasionally what i come across on my own with out regard to my personal taste or to any concerns of "hipness", theme, or curation. MFOA is not a taste maker it is a place for presentation. i do tend to describe and say a few positive words about each submission. i accept the music i receive as an artifact of american folk culture, much like the spiritual forefathers of my site, people like john and alan lomax, harry smith, and other ethnomusicologists and folklorists would have.

The Music Ninja is a multi-genre music discovery site based out of the deep, dark and melodic shadows of the internet. With one simple goal, to only feature the best music we come across, we have swiftly infiltrated the ears and minds of Ke$ha fans and permanently set them on the path to better, more fulfilling music. Discovering music has evolved. Radio committed suicide for repeating the same hits over and over, print magazines are at the brink of extinction and the tubes of the internet are getting clogged with so much bad music, it is nearly impossible to filter through it all. Fortunately, we have been trained in the secret arts of auto-tune detection and mediocre bass lines to bring you digestible daily updates of genuine up and coming artists across all genres whose music truly deserves to be shared. And along the way a couple of fun remixes and mash ups.. lets not take ourselves too seriously now!You can send music ANY way you want .. but its always a plus when I can STREAM music before even before having to download anything) I listen to every single song I receive and try to reply to as many emails as possible.

The idea of creating The Record Stache all came to be while I sat one fine morning, enjoying a nice bowl of Apple Jacks cereal. As I ate, I thought to myself, "This stuff, matter-of-factly, does not taste like apples." Like a giant burst of nostalgia, I had a flashback to the Apple Jacks commercials that aired in the 90's where a group of hip teens were all hanging out on some door step, chowing down their Apple Jacks, and the dad comes out and says something along the lines of, "Why do you guys like that stuff? It doesn't even taste like apples." and then the friends go back and forth with each other trying to come up with a reason why they like the cereal, and all they can come up with is, "We just do." Anywho, the whole catch phrase they based their reasoning for liking Apple Jacks was, "We eat what we like."I wanted a blog to exist that supported new musicians, while at the same time, reviving some forgotten ones. So, just like the Apple Jacks, this blog will be dedicated to "eating what I like." I'm committed to discovering music, new and old, and I'll post whatever catches my ear, no matter what genre it comes from.

SubmissionsWe don_éìt write about new music, but we seriously love reissues. Please send an email to inform us of upcoming reissues you would like to be considered for review.

The Ruckus is a music blog primarily based in Tampa, Florida, and Manchester, England with outlets in London, Toronto, NYC, and several other cities. We photograph and write about new, unsigned, and otherwise lesser known bands all over the world that are 100% worth your time. We have been featured in Creative Loafing and our work has been published in Rolling Stone. We have served as panel judges for The Glastonbury Festival's Emerging Talent Competition for two years running. Our moms think we're cool.While we don't focus on any particular genre, we write a lot about punk, folk, and indie rock music. From time to time, we also review relevant books and other media. With several accomplished photographers on staff, we specialize in concert photography that captures the passion and emotion inherent in a live show. We also present live shows and record acoustic sessions on a regular basis.   Who: Tiffiny, Melanie, and several of our friends.

GENRE: Indie / EDM / Electronic / Alt / Rock / Dream Pop
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: I just love to listen to anything that makes noise, whether it_éìs John Coltrane_éìs sax, Radiohead_éìs method to the madness, Bjork_éìs idiosyncrasies, John Cage_éìs silent spaces or the rattling of a bad muffler. Hopefully, you_éìll read this blog to find new music. Music has never been better or more unique than it is now. Take time out and truly listen to some of what is being created today. I don_éìt have any special qualifications. I_éìm just a dude who digs music. I listen to a lot of it. A lot. Occasionally, I_éìll post some non-music related things. But musically speaking _éå I don_éìt know a thing. I own a guitar and a few harmonicas _éå and play none of them well enough to even suggest I can carry a tune. I can barely write a coherent thought, and love run-on sentences. But _éÙFeel free to send a link to your music. Or go the old-school route and mail an LP, CD or cassette. Please try to include some bio information or a link to something about your band. I can_éìt promise to respond personally to every e-mail because there are just so many now. But realize that I understand all the hard work that goes into making music _éå so believe me when I say everything sent will be read, or listened to in full. I will adhere to any rules you have for posting songs. Take care. And always carry headphones.

This site was created with the intention of sharing great music with anyone who wants to listen. Like many great stories, the idea of Third Outing began around a table covered in pints. We were becoming frustrated with music magazines, we were reading the same old things. So a few days later, the first article went online. Ever since that day we have continued to discover new artists, bands and musicians from all over the world. Based in Edinburgh, UK, Third Outing has become one of the UK's fastest growing music websites. It's true, there are thousands of music magazines, blogs and websites around the world, but at Third Outing, we truly want our readers to discover the latest music from the world of alternative pop culture. So by giving a platform to new artists who are able to freely express themselves about more than just the music, we are giving the fans a true insight into some of their favourite up and coming bands. This is why every article we write is based on an interviews,  so you get the best and most detailed insights possible.

Here I place all the music lying on my head for everyone to listen, and discover. The idea is simple _éç  we will provide a daily dose of 1 song each from our own individual tastes, in the hopes that this site becomes a daily visit for people to discover, or in some cases, re-discover music.  There are countless websites which offer multiple posts and recommendations every day, but that can be overwhelming. That is why we prefer to take time out daily to only focus on two individual songs, which will hopefully allow people the space and time to appreciate a song that we really like.There are no limitations in terms of genre, or era.  What_éìs new and trending doesn_éìt always necessarily mean is good.  We want to maintain an _é£everything goes_éó environment, so even if you don_éìt like what you hear today, you might find something to obsess over in future posts.

Truants is a non-profit and independent blog that mainly focuses on electronic and rap music. Starting out with two writers from Amsterdam early 2010, our team has grown to include over twenty writers who are based throughout Europe, Canada, Australia and The United States. Entitled The Truancy Volumes, our aim is to showcase some of our favourite artists to our readers. We_éìve been placed in the Top 25 of Best Mixtape Series on Mixcloud, alongside Mary-Anne Hobbs and Red Bull Music Radio (_é£The Truants crew left school early to work on their blogging and podcasting. This turned out to be the right decisions, as they have managed to amass one of strongest mix series to date._éó). All our previous instalments are listed here. You can find a more compact overview of our Truancy Volumes and other mixes and giveaways on our SoundCloud.Read more: About | Truants (Beta)

We are True Too. We are a Hip Hop community made by the people and for the people. We aim to offer insight and an enlightened perspective on Hip Hop, our content will be valuable for all types of fans from rap newbies to seasoned veterans.We have writers based around the globe including Sydney, Chicago, LA, DMV, NYC, San Francisco, Canada, London, Dublin, Amsterdam etc. We have a global reach but also stay focused on the local aspect of our individual communities.

Tuneage aims to broaden your musical horizons, be it brand new music or music that's forty years old. If you have something you think we should be listening to, send us an e-mail or use our submission form.

I appreciate all the glittery MySpace-inspired press releases, but to be brutally honest, I have never, and I mean ever, not even once_éåread a press release.  They_éìre just too long, overly wordy, and quite frankly, often times they_éìre missing a specific detail I need such as a Buy Link, to which then I must search the web on my own to find a Buy Link, which often times there isn_éìt one and after 10 minutes of searching I can only ASSUME no Buy Link exists, which means I_éìm still not certain and I COULD very well keep searching but I don_éìt have all day, and it would have been nice to have HAD that information to begin with in your press release, but you were too busy comparing yourself to Nirvana, and then the whole thing makes me so insanely irritated I just wanna stab a hound of puppies with a USB stick.With that said, I don_éìt care if you_éìre black, white, gay, straight, Jewish, Bahai, a frog, a unicorn, or an amoeba.  I don_éìt need pictures of you, or the city you_éìre from, or what your influences are.  The 6 pieces of information are: BAND NAME:  SONG NAME:  ALBUM NAME:  ALBUM YEAR:  BUY LINK:    SONG LINK:

Tunesday is the smallest big music blog on the internet, but somehow we_éìre listed on hype machine which I suppose brings some level of credibility.Despite the curmudgeonly negativity on the state of music and the music industry you_éìll often hear amongst pub discourses, I maintain that there are bucket loads of fantastic tracks being produced left, right and centre if you look in the right places (but if you look in the wrong places, you might end up here).But ultimately, this is where I post and muse on the tracks I like, with a focus on emerging independent Australian bands and artists.*

An Americana Music Magazine"Waiting for the day when they stop calling it Americana and start calling it Country again."It's Gonzo Journalism meets Outlaw Country as Turnstyled, Junkpiled shakes shaking things up in the Sin City. Sort of like if Creem Magazine was L.A.'s ONLY Americana Magazine.

Twang Nation is one of those kind of shining lights in the ever-growing darkness that is the non-mainstream country landscape. Besides being a reputable, fair and good-spirited source for all things country and Americana, Twang Nation also offers a refreshingly pure look at the underground and independent side of southern music

Twangville began in early 2005 by humble means as a place to post playlists for our friends. It wasn_éìt long before we expanded to covering releases, reviews, downloads, links and more. Ultimately, we just want to help spread the word about some of our favorite musicians who often don_éìt get the credit they deserve. In search of twang, we typically look beyond traditional and mainstream country into genres like americana, alt-country, indie, rock, folk and blues _éÙ or just about anything that features a guitar. You_éìll find that we tend to emphasize the alternative side of alt-country.   As of 2012, we_éìre moving toward digital submissions as our primary means of receiving music for review. You can either email us or upload safely and securely through ReviewShine to save some stamps, reduce fuel consumption, and most importantly to get music to us sooner. Music submitted through ReviewShine will directly notify our most active reviewers of your requests. Just sign up as a promoter, upload your album and click _é£Twangville_éó (amongst others) as the blog you want to submit to.We are happy to accept solicited material but cannot make any guarantee that your submission will make it onto the site. Additionally, we reserve the right to post a track of our choosing from any received material unless otherwise specified by the sender. Please keep in mind that submissions that come ready with permission to post a song will receive priority.

My name is Britta Verheeken, I was born in 1991. Last school year, I completed my Master interior. I did this to Luca School of Arts in Ghent. Now I'm working with the Bachelor Graphic and Digital Media at Artevelde in Gent, firmly convinced that there is much cohesion between interior and graphics.I have a soft spot for both the analog and the digital way of working. This is especially evident in my photos, designs , taste in music and traveling. I love culture in the broadest sense of the word, and there is an expression of this blog, all records music still the guiding principle.Normally, I am curious and excited, I almost always have something to say and I like to store in my head. Most crazy facts and news I unwind by making things and love to explore.   http://tweehuizenverder.wordpress.com/contact/

Tweendie is a French and independant music webzine created in 2009 by a team of volunteers. Its purpose is to share and spread its authors' passion towards a selection of contemporary pop acts (mainly from the indiepop scene).
News for your muse
Music blog based in France

GENRE: Indie / EDM / Electronic / Jazz / Hip Hop / Soul / All
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Twistedsoul (that_éìs how we like our music) is a music blog which looks beyond the mainstream and seeks out new artist  which we hope you will love.We are continually exploring new music from all genres be it, Electronic, Jazz, Rock, Hip-Hop, Soul, RnB and many more styles.If we like it we will cover it. As well as the new stuff we also like looking back at some of the originators,whose influence make todays music possible.Enjoy the music and support the artist.

I'm Matt, some 18 year old kid who thinks he knows metal. I do reviews and interviews of some pretty well known bands including Death, Cynic, All Shall Perish and Revocation. I live in Paris and really dig my local scene.

TWM is the brainchild of Dan Wolovick, starting as a humble blog with only one or two writers, it expanded to a series of live shows and now a full-time booking gig at venues like Rancho Relaxo, Handlebar, Horseshoe Tavern, Measure and now expanding into Ottawa, Montreal, Halifax and St. John_éìs Newfoundland. Recently Dan has added Antony East as a partner for the live shows in Toronto. TWM has continued to exist in blog-form with a rotating cast of contributers covering the Toronto independent music scene and beyond.

GENRE: Indie / Pop / Alt / Low Fi / Rock
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: A music blog based in Rochester, NY that specializes in the unappreciated and under-appreciated in today\\\'s music  an examination used to test the condition of the middle ear and mobility of the eardrum, and the conduction bones by creating variations of air pressure in the ear canal.Basically, it sounded like a cool name for a blog intended to be primarily about music. We_éìd both had other blogs previously, but over beers it was decided that more damage could be done as a joint venture. And here we are.We share a passion for the undiscovered and under-appreciated, and hope that you_éìll be able to find something you love as well.
Independent Hip Hop Magazine. Est. 2000
Ultimate Music is a music web that offers all the news regarding the upcoming releases of your favorite artists. It also tries to discover new talent and make them known to all its followers
Your premier source for all the latest music happenings in and around the Mile-High City. Concert reviews, photos, interviews and more

1) 'Ultra Media Blog Submission' in subject of email.  2) Social media networks (Twitter, Facebook, YouTube) 3) Bio, Recent Photo, Single/Mixtape Cover Art. 4) Submit recent material only! 5) Upload music to (Sharebeast, Soundcloud, YouTube), or submit CDQ mp3. 6) Upload videos to (YouTube) 7) Music producer, video director, mixtape DJ.  - See more at: http://ultramedia.blogspot.com/p/contact-us_03.html#sthash.TAV2fjRG.dpuf

Ultra Vulgar Super Fiend is a community of like-minded tastemakers who refuse to shut the fuck up. We_éìve never been great at keeping promises, but we will endeavor to bring you entertaining, hilarious, and insightful news about potential fun to be had, music that ruined your hearing, food to be grubbed on, fashion to be haughty about, hot fucks that may have been mistakes, films that changed your perspective, drugs you don_éìt remember doing, and all the latest hedonistic trends

November 2012, founder Amandah Opoku launched UMusicians as a place to showcase talent by artists in the _é£underground_éó music site, mainly in the form of interviews and minimum news updates. That year, Amandah also launched _é£12 Days of Music (Christmas)_éó which has now become an annual feature on the site.January of 2013 saw the expansion of the content and artists offered on the site with the help of co-founder Brittany Ginyard. The websites features came to include a variety of features, which offered more opportunities for artists to be featured on the site. The expansion put an emphasis on what was truly important; the music
UNCANNY is a Japanese webzine in that we introduce independent music, labels and artists.

album reviews, roundups, interviews and the _é£Listen to_éó sections are to introduce you to new artists, artists you may have missed or to remind you that someone is still around.I_éìm always looking for suggestions and ideas, so if you can think of someone that would fit well here go ahead and email me.
Hip Hop is a way of life

Under Bright Lights was created to express love and admiration for all things music. From well known bands to bands that are just getting started, our goal is to cover it all. We are mostly focused on reviewing albums and concerts but we are always looking to shed some light on bands that we feel are, or at least should be, the next big thing.

UndercoverRockLife is a Milan-based music blog that focuses on independent music, ranging from upcoming artists to established artists.Undercover Rock Life is a selection of what I like_éÙwhat I listen to_éÙor simply the music that drives me in all these years. All you can listen to and read about on these pages is selected and written by me, your secret agent which surfs through the blogosphere in searching for music that worth and guide you in the best way I know.

GENRE: Indie / Alt / All / Rock / Acoustic / EDM
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Under the Radar is an indie music magazine that prints five issues a year, is distributed across North America and internationally, and bills itself as _é£The solution to music pollution._éó The independent magazine was founded in 2001 by publishers (and now husband and wife) Mark Redfern (a writer) and Wendy Lynch Redfern (a photographer) and is known for in-depth and characterized interviews with bands large and small, as well as their accompanying unique and stylistic photo-shoots. It offers intelligent, and sometimes humorous, articles that go far beyond a band_éìs major influences, often accompanied by exclusive photo shoots. Under the Radar conducted the last interview and photo-shoot with the late Elliott Smith in 2003 and also garnered media attention for its 2004 and 2008 music and politics issues (The Protest Issues) and their associated charity auctions that benefited such organizations as War Child. The tastemaking publication strives to be ahead of the curve, interviewing exciting young artists months or years before the mainstream media catches on and has helped to break such artists as Fleet Foxes and Vampire Weekend, being the first nationally distributed print magazine to interview either of those bands. Under the Radar was also an early supporter of artists like Bright Eyes, Interpol, Death Cab for Cutie, Rilo Kiley, M. Ward, TV on the Radio, and Feist, and was the first American magazine to interview such international artists as The Duke Spirit, Friendly Fires, Glasvegas, The Pipettes, The Dears, Mew, Los Campesinos!, Mystery Jets, The Go! Team, Editors, Love Is All, and many others. Each issue includes up to 200 reviews of the most interesting releases in music, film, television, DVDs, books, comic books, and video games. Under the Radar_éìs website features web-exclusive reviews, news, interviews, and media, as well as an extensive archive of back issue content.

GENRE: Indie / Alt / All / Rock / Acoustic / EDM
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Under the Radar is an indie music magazine that prints five issues a year, is distributed across North America and internationally, and bills itself as _é£The solution to music pollution._éó The independent magazine was founded in 2001 by publishers (and now husband and wife) Mark Redfern (a writer) and Wendy Lynch Redfern (a photographer) and is known for in-depth and characterized interviews with bands large and small, as well as their accompanying unique and stylistic photo-shoots. It offers intelligent, and sometimes humorous, articles that go far beyond a band_éìs major influences, often accompanied by exclusive photo shoots. Under the Radar conducted the last interview and photo-shoot with the late Elliott Smith in 2003 and also garnered media attention for its 2004 and 2008 music and politics issues (The Protest Issues) and their associated charity auctions that benefited such organizations as War Child. The tastemaking publication strives to be ahead of the curve, interviewing exciting young artists months or years before the mainstream media catches on and has helped to break such artists as Fleet Foxes and Vampire Weekend, being the first nationally distributed print magazine to interview either of those bands. Under the Radar was also an early supporter of artists like Bright Eyes, Interpol, Death Cab for Cutie, Rilo Kiley, M. Ward, TV on the Radio, and Feist, and was the first American magazine to interview such international artists as The Duke Spirit, Friendly Fires, Glasvegas, The Pipettes, The Dears, Mew, Los Campesinos!, Mystery Jets, The Go! Team, Editors, Love Is All, and many others. Each issue includes up to 200 reviews of the most interesting releases in music, film, television, DVDs, books, comic books, and video games. Under the Radar_éìs website features web-exclusive reviews, news, interviews, and media, as well as an extensive archive of back issue content.

Vanyaland is an online music magazine curated and published by outgoing Boston Phoenix music editor Michael Marotta. After the closing of the storied alt-weekly in March 2013, Marotta shifted his efforts and vision for Boston music coverage to his personal blog, Vanyaland, with the idea of expanding its scope to cover the vibrant Boston music scene from the basements and clubs of Allston, Somerville, and Cambridge to the larger theatres and music venues all over town.....Re-launched May 2013, on the one year anniversary of the sale of WFNX_éìs 101.7 FM signal, Vanyaland is an interactive source for music news, live shows, new releases, downloads, live streams, and nightlife around Boston and beyond, focusing on the bands raised in our city but also welcoming to the touring acts that pass through it daily. It_éìs a destination to learn about the musical pulse of Boston, from venues to record stores to other entities that make our city the best in the world.

NAME OF BLOG: We Do It For The Love Of Music
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: After growing tired and frustrated of being spoon fed generic, manufactured, and synthetic _é£music_éó by conglomerate owned radio stations and a small niche of industry insiders, Shawn McMurray and Kathryn Wood decided to put the _é£art_éó back in _é£artist_éó by starting wedoitfortheloveofmusic.com in April 2011. Headquartered in Miami and with representatives in California, Utah, Nevada, Kansas, and Virginia, this site and network is truly focused on giving undiscovered artists the chance to be seen and heard by the masses. Taking the spotlight off of the four or five overplayed flavors of the month, wedoitfortheloveofmusic.com gives a worldwide platform to all genres of music, art, and dance.
we fucking love music is a blog about awesome music

WESTAYCHILL is a site dedicated to everything in the world. Music, Fashion, Technology, Culture, you can find it all here at WESTAYCHILL. We don't only discover the new first, we personally introduce you to it as well.

We-Are-Awesome was started in late 2007 by Andrew Berry and Sean Sassen, who took it upon themselves to document what was happening in their city. This Capecentric approach quickly grew into a platform that provided support for all South African artists, musicians, festivals, photographers and other creative work deserving its fifteen minutes in the spotlight.

Our Mission StatementWeird Canada exists to encourage, connect, and document creative expression across Canada.Our valuesWe are a space for artistic, literary, and musical enthusiasm.We aim to connect the disparate communities that feed the creative cosmos of Canada.We capture the physical ephemera that contains and surrounds art, literature, and music.We welcome the makers of art, literature, and music who take risks and experiment.We welcome excited minds.Our obligationsWe will treat all living beings with dignity and respect. We will listen to each other, and try to understand each other. We will challenge ourselves to be kinder and smarter human beings.We acknowledge that we are biased, and accept that our bias is not always visible. We strive to make this bias visible, and challenge our relationship with it. We do not tolerate racism, homophobia, misogyny, or any other body-based discrimination.We exist to encourage, connect, and document creative expression across Canada.Our movements should reflect our vision, and we will remain open to and excited about creativity and community.PS _éç This site exists to promote obscure bands; however, if any artist would like to have their mp3s removed, just contact us and they will be taken down promptly.We have a lot of fun playing with hyperbole.

WEIRD MAGIC IS_éÙ.weird magic is a portalweird magic is a partyweird magic is a neverending playlistweird magic is an artistweird magic is a vibei try to let the images and music speak for themselves_éÙweird magic is run by erez avissar and pals in brooklyn, berlin, and beyond.our range is unconstrained to any categorization or date. we eat what we like

GENRE: All / Metal / Jazz / Hip Hop / Indie
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Bloggers Andy and Jake write about bands both successful and obscure, whether metal, jazz, hip-hop, or whatever other genre, always with an unflagging appreciation for what makes these bands unique, and with none of the snark and jeering that often laces articles elsewhere about people doing weird things.

Our mission is to write high quality feature pieces on AUS/NZ bands and musicians, with the goal of increasing the awareness of their output to the rest of AUS/NZ and beyond.Weirdo Wasteland hopes to give a new platform for music artists to talk about their projects with a lot more attention to detail. With a sharp focus on the inspiration and background of each band, we wish to share the ideas and progress of these creative individuals with the wider community.With our feature length articles and reviews, we put time and effort into allowing local talent to express their ideas and goals with plenty of room for analysis and interpretation.
Hello, my name is Nana and I'm the editor and writer for The Playlist.This blog was established October 2012. It is based out of Washington D.C., USA.

COUNTRY / LOCATION: Los Angeles, CA / NY, NY, USA
DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: A music blog born on the west coast of the USA and currently based on both coasts. We're a team of creative people that enjoy writing about and connecting global music scenes. When contacting us, keep in mind we see every email but due to high volume keep in mind we can't respond to all. For tips on how to reach out to blogs see this article.

Artist management, music over-enthusiast, linguaphile, lover of nature...overall aesthete The number of people who have pushed me to do this through the years must range in the hundreds now. Truth be told, I have purposefully avoided the blogosphere for many reasons, the main ones being self-absorption and time. I am not one who enjoys any sort of spotlight, whatever the kind. And who knows where I will find the bandwidth to make this work_éÙI work in the music business and am a firm believer that great music surrounds us at all times. There is such an overwhelming number of avenues for our musical intake and discovery these days that most listeners are understandably left empty-handed. It takes patience and effort to dig through it all. And I happen to really enjoy that process. Few things give me more pleasure than introducing someone to their future new favorite band or song.To keep it short and sweet, this is a music blog for all types of listeners, not the usual weed-through-a-zillion-reverby-oh-so-indie-tracks-and-maybe-find-one-good-one kind of blog. Not that I have anything against reverb (I actually really like it), but I think those of you who are plugged into the music blog scene know what I mean. Everything I post will be accessible. I am not a musician. I simply love music and seem to have a sharp ear that people trust."

Firstly its pronounced Who Knows_éÙ I know, clever right? Anyway, house is such a broad term these days, thrown around like an old toy handed down to your sister_éìs husband_éìs second cousin, twice removed, whom you_éìve only seen once (or did you just hear about them), but still that toy gets around. Whono_éìs music blog grabs the inspiration from a whole bunch of random DJs with all different house music styles. Tech, deep, funk, commercial, pop, some minimal, even a bit of those Melbourne bangers you know so much about, the ones that go do do di da da boom ba da, you know. So if you like house in general, electronic music, or just a specific type of club tune, Whono_éìs music will probably have some, most, or all of it.

Winniecooper.net is a Vancouver based music and events e-zine founded in 2008.Since it_éìs inception, Winniecooper has been visited by over one and a half million visitors from around the world.Winniecooper.net puts on around 50 local shows/events a year.Winnie has had the pleasure of hosting emerging artists such as The Local Natives, Das Racist, Big Freedia, Austra, Diamond Rings, Gobble Gobble, Grimes, Braids and more (that probably you haven_éìt heard of yet) to play in Vancouver for the first time.Winnie has also been the first site to feature internationally renown locals such as Oh No! Yoko, Teen Daze, Humans, Makeout Videotape, Babe Rainbow, Young Liars and Shimmering Stars putting on some of their first ever live shows.We are devoted to the artists we love. Here we talk openly about our secret crushes. We share art with our readers: music, film/television & photography, but mostly music."

Why WithGuitars, I imagine you_éìre thinking? As most of the music we will cover could be described, by lazy hacks, as _éïguitar music_éì it made sense. More to the point,  I am a big fan of The Clash _éç the line _é£With Guitars!_éó is a Mick Jones reply to Joe Strummer_éìs announcement of the next song _éïEnglish Civil War_éì.WithGuitars features the writing skills of a few former national editors of indie, alternative,  and rock magazine titles, add to the mix some of the best writers around _éç here_éìs the part when I drop some names, John Robb, Chris Merriman, John Esplen, Chris Todd, Martin Herron, Ian Weiss, Jamie Morrell, Chris Storey and Jamie Gambino,  to go on would be just showing off. Rest assured more details of who_éìs who will be posted here shortly.

DESCRIPTION / AUTHORS WORDS: Wondering Sound was born out of a sense of need. As we looked around the cultural landscape, we noticed that fewer and fewer places were devoting space to the kind of long-form storytelling, spirited interviews and rousing criticism that once defined music journalism, and those sites that did weren_éìt focusing on the artists we felt were important.Our goal with Wondering Sound isn_éìt to sell music, but to share it, regardless of what label it_éìs on, if it_éìs available digitally, or if fewer than 50 people have even heard of it. We_éìll cover things because we think they_éìre interesting and worth knowing about _éå whether it_éìs an in-depth piece on the anniversary of a groundbreaking jazz record, or a profile of a kid making brain-rattling music in his bedroom with a thrift store keyboard and a four-track. Our entire ethos is right there in our name, which was taken from a song by Family Band: we_éìrethinking about music, and we_éìre putting an emphasis on artists who are doing the same _éå artists who are fascinated with the possibilities of sound, who have a distinct, singular, uncompromising point-of-view and who are dedicated to testing the boundaries of what_éìs been done before."

The Word Is Bond.Com is more than just a website. We are the embodiment of a movement striving towards the growth of the arts. As a team of dedicated writers, we try our best to deliver quality hip-hop music and articles.Now more than ever, fans of hip-hop look for sites that can provide an alternative to mainstream boredom. Here you will find all sorts of underground gems, but mostly you will find the truth. Unlike many other publications, our reviews aren_éìt biased, nor will we try and _éïsell_éì you an artist.We appreciate your feedback and comments, building a community; we can honour the emcees that are over-looked and under valued. Each section of the site will bring a different element to the blog, which will allow you to explore our vision for the future, one which is not tied down by commercial constraints."

When I was a kid I attended my aunt_éìs wedding. All I noticed was the food and music. Those junior high dances? Food and music. Birthday parties? Food and music. Social gatherings? Food and music. Activisim opportunites? Food and music. So it was only natural that when I felt the need to start a blog I combined the two things that have been constants in my life. The original intention of Write.Click.Cook.Listen was for me to create a recipe and attach music to it. Throughout the years it has expanded to include band submitted recipes, artist interviews, songs about food, food themed playlists and restaurant reviews. No matter which direction the blog goes in, the same two interests remain at the heart of it. Food and music.

The Yonge Street Portage is an online forum for engaging discussion about poetry, prose, and politics, literary news and critical reviews. The Portage features a wide array of content and mediums: from video blogs to podcasts, short stories to oil paintings, YSP is a hub for artistic expression. _é£Expression_éó is perhaps the most important word on this page: we want to hear from you, engage with you, and even feature your work.
